[[University of Teesside]] | influences = | influenced = | contributions = | awards = | signature = | repec_prefix = | repec_id = }} '''Ayelet Gneezy''' (born August 25, 1966) is an associate professor of marketing at the [[Rady School of Management]], UC San Diego. ==Education and career== Gneezy obtained her MBA at the [[University of Teesside]] joint with the [[Haagse Hogeschool]]. She went on to manage the strategic planning department in DataPro Proximity (a subsidiary of [[BBDO]]) in Israel, before receiving her PhD in [[marketing]] at the [[University of Chicago Graduate School of Business]] in 2007.http://rady.ucsd.edu/faculty/directory/ayelet-gneezy/ Gneezy teaches [[marketing communications]], [[social entrepreneurship]] and [[consumer behavior]] to MBA students at the [[University of California, San Diego]]. ==Research== Gneezy's research addresses various questions regarding consumer behavior, including social preferences, prosocial behavior, behavioral pricing, and factors influencing quality of life for individuals. She collaborates with both small and large firms and integrates field experiments in order to answer this questions. In a 2010 study,http://www.sciencemag.org/content/329/5989/325.full Gneezy and coauthors worked with [[Disney Research]] to study a behavioral pricing approach called [[pay-what-you-want]] at an amusement park. In a large-scale field experiment, they sold people souvenir photos from a ride at the park under four conditions. In the first of these, the photos were priced at the regular $12.95; about 0.5% (1 in 200) of people bought a photo in this condition. In the second condition, the price stayed the same but consumers were told that half of the proceeds would go to charity, which resulted in about 0.57% of people buying the photos.http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2013/jul/29/tp-professor-naming-own-price-can-be-a-success/ The third condition allowed people to pay what they want for the photos, which resulted in 16 times more sales, but at prices so low that they were unsustainable. In the final condition, Gneezy and her coauthors offered the consumers the option to pay what they want and told them half of the proceeds would go to charity. The results of the final condition were astonishing; the amusement park profited significantly from this condition, along with a considerable amount of money being raised for the charity. This demonstrated what Gneezy and her colleagues refer to as "shared social responsibility" – the idea that involving the consumer in the pricing of goods and the choice of contributions increases the benefit to both the consumers and the company. The results of this study received widespread media attention and have inspired many more studies and experiments. Gneezy and coauthors are credited for playing a major role as pioneers in pay-what-you-want research. They won the 2012 Society for Personality and Social Psychology Robert B. Cialdini Award for excellence in a published field study. ==Personal life== Gneezy lives with her husband and three children in [[San Diego]], California. ==Academic publications== http://rady.ucsd.edu/faculty/directory/ayelet-gneezy/ * Baca-Motes, K., Brown, A., Gneezy, A. Keenan, E. and Nelson, L. D. (2013). Commitment and behavior change: Evidence from the field. Journal of Consumer Research, 39, 1070–84. * Gneezy, A., Gneezy, U., Riener, G., & Nelson, L. D. (2012). Pay-What-You-Want, Identity, and Self-Signaling, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(19): 7236–40. * Gneezy, A., Imas, A., Nelson, L. D., Brown, A., and Norton, M. I. (2012). Paying to be Nice: Costly Prosocial Behavior and Consistency, Management Science, 58:179–87. * Gneezy, A. and Fessler D.T. (2011). Conflict, sticks and carrots: war increases prosocial punishments and rewards . Proceedings of the Royal Society B., published online before print June 8, 2011, doi:10.1098/rspb.2011.0805 * Gneezy, A., Gneezy, U., Nelson, L. D. and Brown, A. (2010). Shared Social Responsibility: A Field Experiment in Pay-What-You-Want Pricing and Charitable Giving. Science, 329 (5989), 325–27. * Epley, N., & Gneezy, A. (2007). The Framing of Financial Windfalls and Implications for Public Policy. Journal of Socio-Economics, 36, 36–47. * Gneezy, A., & Epley, N. (2007). Prospect Theory. In R. Baumeister, & K. D. Vohs (Eds.), Encyclopedia of Social Psychology (Vol. 2, 711–14). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gneezy, Ayelet}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Marketing people]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:University of California, San Diego faculty]] [[Category:1966 births]]

[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-1986-0226-333, Bonn, Besuch Volkskammer-Delegation, Sindermann cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Berthold Beitz (1986)]]
'''Berthold Beitz''' (26 September 1913 – 30 July 2013) was a German industrialist. He was the head of the [[ThyssenKrupp|Krupp]] steel conglomerate beginning in the 1950s. He was credited with helping to lead the re-industrialization of the [[Ruhr Valley]] and rebuilding [[Germany]] into an industrial power. He gained acclaim for saving some 250 [[Jew]]ish workers during [[World War II]] by declaring them to be essential workers at an oil facility in [[Poland]]. In 1973, for saving Jews, he received the [[Righteous Among the Nations]] title awarded by the [[Israel]]i [[Yad Vashem]], the highest honor given to a non-Jew.
==Early years== Beitz was born in 1913 in [[Bentzin|Zemmin]], [[Hither Pomerania]]. He began his career as a banker at the "Pommersche Bank" in [[Stralsund]] and started to work for [[Shell Oil Company]] in [[Hamburg]] in 1938.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|title=Berthold Beitz, German Steel Industrialist Who Saved Jews, Dies at 99|first= Melissa |last= Eddy|date=August 1, 2013 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/02/business/berthold-beitz-german-steel-industrialist-who-saved-jews-dies-at-99.html?ref=obituaries}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Beitz, Eine deutsche Geschichte |language=de |trans-title=Beitz, A German History |first= Norbert F. |last= Pötzl |publisher=Heyne |date=2011 | accessdate= August 3, 2013 |oclc=948635931 |isbn=9783641068110 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=6oIpJpM31T8C&pg=PT33}}</ref>
==World War II== Beitz remained in the employ of Shell Oil when World War II began in 1939. Following Germany's invasion and occupation of [[Boryslav|Borysław]] in July 1941, Beitz was assigned to supervise the Carpathian Oil Company operating the [[Boryslav|Borysław]] oil fields in what is now [[Ukraine]]. Given the importance of the oil fields to the German war effort, Beitz was able to designate workers as essential to the war effort.<ref name=YV>{{cite web|title=Berthold and Elsa Beitz|publisher=Yad Vashem|accessdate=August 2, 2013|url=http://www.yad-vashem.org.il/yv/en/righteous/stories/beitz.asp}}</ref> The Borysław area had a large Jewish population, with many Jews holding positions as chemical engineers, laboratory assistants, mechanics, and laborers in the area's oil industry.<ref name=YV/>
After witnessing the "Invaliden-Aktion" in August 1942, an [[Schutzstaffel|SS]]-led evacuation of a Jewish orphanage in Borysław, Beitz became determined to act to save local Jews. Having a position of importance, Beitz received advance word of Nazi actions against local Jews and provided warning to the Jewish community. He also had the opportunity to select suitable workers from Jews who were being held at transfer points for deportation to concentration camps. In August 1942, he "extricated 250 Jewish men and women from the transport train to the [[Belzec extermination camp]] by claiming them as 'professional workers.'"<ref name=YV/><ref name=DW>{{cite news |title= Berthold Beitz, ThyssenKrupp patriarch who saved wartime Jews, dies aged 99| publisher= Deutsche Welle| date=31 July 2013|url=http://www.dw.de/berthold-beitz-thyssenkrupp-patriarch-who-saved-wartime-jews-dies-aged-99/a-16990234}}</ref> Beitz recalled, "I should have employed qualified personnel. Instead, I chose tailors, hairdressers and Talmudic scholars and gave them all cards as vital 'petroleum technicians.'"<ref name=Aus/>
Together with his wife Else, Beitz also hid Jews in his home.<ref name=YV/><ref name=JWN/><ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title=German magnate Berthold Beitz who saved Jews in WWII dies|publisher=BBC|date=July 31, 2013|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-23522382}}</ref> He also issued and signed fake work permits to save other Jews from the death camps.<ref name=JWN>{{cite news|title=Berthold Beitz, savior of hundreds of Jews during the Holocaust, dies at 99|newspaper=Jewish World News|date=August 1, 2013|url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/jewish-world-news/.premium-1.539040}}</ref> In 1943, Beitz's efforts were nearly exposed after two Jewish girls were arrested on a train to [[Hungary]] with forged "Aryan" permits signed by Beitz. Beitz survived despite a Gestapo investigation into the incident, but he was drafted into the German army in March 1944.<ref name=YV/> In total, Beitz has been credited with saving the lives of 800 Jews.<ref name=Aus>{{cite web|title=Berthold Beitz|publisher=Auschwitz.com|accessdate=August 2, 2013|url=http://auschwitz.dk/rescuers/id16.htm}}</ref>
Beitz later explained his motivation: "I saw how people were shot, how they were lined up in the night. My motives were not political; they were purely humane, moral motives."<ref name=NYT/> In another interview, he explained: "It wasn't anti-Fascism, nor was it resistance. We saw from dawn to dusk, as close as could be, what was happening to Boryslav's Jews. When you see a mother holding her children being shot, while you yourself have children, your reaction has to be completely different."<ref name=JWN/>
For his efforts in saving Jewish workers, Beitz received Poland's highest civilian honor.<ref name=NYT/> In 1973, he was also honored by [[Yad Vashem]], the Israeli Holocaust memorial, as a "Righteous Among the Nations", the organization's highest honor for non-Jews who saved Jews from the Holocaust.<ref name=DW/> According to Yad Vashem, "The Jews that he rescued from deportation included many unqualified workers, often in poor physical condition, who could not, by any stretch of the imagination, be described as 'professionals' or indispensable to the oil industry."<ref name=YV/>
==Post-war business career== After the war, Beitz became the head of Iduna, an insurance company. His innovative business methods and compensation brought him attention. In 1953, [[Alfried Krupp]] hired him to become chairman of the [[Friedrich Krupp AG|Krupp]] steel corporation. He remained with the company for 60 years and helped build it into a publicly traded conglomerate, merging the company in the 1990s to form [[ThyssenKrupp]]. Beitz has also been credited with helping to lead the re-industrialization of the [[Ruhr Valley]] where Krupp's operations were based.<ref name=NYT/>
After Alfried Krupp's death in 1967, Beitz served as executor and persuaded the Krupp heirs to establish a charitable foundation known as the [[Alfried Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach Foundation]]. The foundation still owns 25% of ThyssenKrupp.<ref name=NYT/> Beitz remained active in the foundation and led its effort to fund the creation of the [[Museum Folkwang]] in [[Essen]].<ref name=NYT/>
From 1972 to 1988, Beitz was a member of the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) and an honorary member until his death. From 1984 to 1988, he was an IOC vice president and executive board member.<ref>{{cite web|title=Death of Berthold Beitz, IOC Honorary Member|publisher=Olympic.org |date=July 31, 2013|url=http://www.olympic.org/news/death-of-berthold-beitz-ioc-honorary-member/206954}}</ref>
In 2000, he received the Leo-Baeck Award, the highest honor bestowed by the [[Central Council of Jews in Germany]].<ref name=BBC/><ref>{{cite news|title=Berthold Beitz: Industrialist who saved hundreds of Jews from the Nazis|newspaper=The Independent|date=August 1, 2013|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/berthold-beitz-industrialist-who-saved-hundreds-of-jews-from-the-nazis-8742688.html}}</ref>
In July 2013, Beitz died at age 99 at his holiday home on the island of [[Sylt]] off the northern coast of Germany.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thyssen-Krupp-Chef Hiesinger: "Verneige mich" vor Patriarch Beitz|newspaper=Spiegel|date=August 2, 2013|url=http://www.spiegel.de/thema/berthold_beitz/}}</ref> He is survived by his wife Else and three daughters.<ref name=NYT/> Following Beitz's death, [[Ronald Lauder]], president of the [[World Jewish Congress]], called Beitz "one of the great Germans of the past century."<ref name=DW/>
==Honours== <ref>From the article in the German Wikipedia</ref>
===Decorations=== *Commander with Star of the Order of Merit of the [[People's Republic of Poland]] (1974) *Honorary Ring of the city of [[Essen]] (1983) *Order of Merit of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] (1986) *Grand Cross 1st Class of the [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]] (1987; Grand Cross 2nd Class: 1979; Grand Officer's Cross: 1973; Commander's Cross: 1971) *Grand Decoration of Honour in Gold with Star for Services to the [[Republic of Austria]] (1990) *Order of Cultural Merit of the [[Republic of Korea]] (2001) *Order of Merit of [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]] (2012)
===Awards=== *"Righteous Among the Nations" at [[Yad Vashem]] (Israel) for the help to persecuted Jews in the Nazi period (1973) *Honorary doctorate from the Ernst-Moritz-Arndt [[University of Greifswald]] (1983) *Honorary senator of the Ernst-Moritz-Arndt University of Greifswald (1991) *Honorary doctorate from the [[Jagiellonian University]] in [[Cracow]] (1993) *Honorary citizen of the university and Hanseatic City of Greifswald (1995) *Honorary doctorate from the [[Weizmann Institute of Science]] (1996) *Josef Neuberger Medal, together with his wife Else Beitz (1997) *Honorary doctorate from the [[Ruhr University Bochum]], because of his "ministry of science and education in the Ruhr area" (1999) *[[Leo Baeck]] Prize of the Central Council of Jews in Germany, together with his wife Else Beitz (1999) *Leibniz Medal of the [[Berlin-Brandenburg Academy of Sciences]] (2000) *Honorary citizen of the city of [[Kiel]] (2003) *Honorary citizen of the city of [[Bochum]] during the ceremony for the 40th birthday at the Ruhr University Bochum (2005) *Honorary senator of the [[German Academy of Sciences Leopoldina]] (since 2008, National Academy of Sciences) (2005) *Honorary citizen of the city of Essen (single award since 1949) naming the new road through the former Krupp factory premises at the new ThyssenKrupp Headquarters as Berthold Beitz Boulevard (2007) *Hall of Fame of German Sport (2008) *The Chair for Human Rights at [[Harvard University]] on the science campus of the Ernst-Moritz-Arndt-University of Greifswald is named the Berthold Beitz place after the chairman of the Alfried Krupp von Bohlen and Halbach named Foundation, which promotes university and city for years (2008) *[[Moses Mendelssohn]] Medal for the rescue of persecuted Jews (2010) *Honorary senator of the College of Jewish Studies in [[Heidelberg]] (2010) *State Prize of North Rhine-Westphalia with his wife Else Beitz (2011) *[[Lew Kopelew]] Prize (2012) *Emperor Leopold I Medal of the German Academy of Natural Scientists Leopoldina (2012) *Honorary citizen of the [[University of Duisburg-Essen]] *Honorary citizen of [[Gerlos]], [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]]

The '''Broad Agency Announcement (BAA)''' is a technique for [[Federal government of the United States|United States government]] agencies to solicit proposals from outside groups for certain research and development. The agency will then select proposals to fund as contracts or grants. BAAs are broad in their subject matter and focus on advancing science rather than acquiring specific products, which are instead covered under a [[Request for proposals]].<ref name=":0">[http://www.acquisition.gov/far/current/html/Subpart%2035_0.html#wp1085187 FAR 35.016]. Retrieved January 14, 2015.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.niaid.nih.gov/researchfunding/glossary/pages/b.aspx#baa |title=NIAID Glossary of Funding and Policy Terms and Acronyms—B |publisher=National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases |accessdate=2016-04-12 |date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
BAAs pertains to basic and [[Research|applied research]], and certain early-stage development work. They are not intended for acquisition "related to the development of a specific system or hardware procurement." It may only be used "when meaningful proposals with varying technical/scientific approaches can reasonably be foreseen."<ref name=":0"/>
The technique may be used to acquire "scientific study and experimentation directed toward advancing the state-of-the-art or increasing knowledge or understanding." The technique shares the name of the means of initiating it.<ref name=":0"/> The announcement, published in ''Federal Business Opportunities'',<ref>[http://www.fbo.gov Federal Business Opportunities]. Retrieved January 14, 2015.</ref> describes "broadly defined areas of interest".<ref name=":0"/> Proposals received in response to the announcement are evaluated through a peer or scientific review process,<ref name=":0"/> unlike the more traditional technique for evaluation of proposals under FAR Subpart 15.3<ref>[http://www.acquisition.gov/far/current/html/Subpart%2015_3.html#wp1088864 FAR Subpart 15.3]. Retrieved January 14, 2015.</ref> An award under the technique is treated as meeting the statutory requirement in the Competition in Contracting Act for full and open competition (vis a [[no-bid contract]]).<ref>[http://www.acquisition.gov/far/current/html/Subpart%206_1.html#wp1087648 48 CFR 6.102(d)(2)]. Retrieved January 14, 2015.</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Carlos Juan Molinari | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | occupation = businessman, real-estate developer }} '''Carlos Juan Molinari''' is an [[Argentina|Argentinian]] businessman and real-estate developer<ref name=perfil>{{cite web| last =Morando| first =Lucas| title =Molinari, el magnate con lazos políticos detrás del escándalo| work =Perfil| date =Apr 21, 2013| url = http://www.perfil.com/politica/Molinari-el-magnate-con-lazos-politicos-detras-del-escandalo-20130421-0001.html}}</ref> who runs a firm called Real Estate Investments (REI) Sociedad Fiduciaria, also known as Rei Fiduciaria. He also runs many other firms in Argentina, the U.S., and elsewhere, and resides in [[Buenos Aires]] and [[Miami]].<ref name=fortuna>{{cite web| title =Carlos Molinari: del barrio cerrado a las viviendas sociales | work =FortunaWeb| url = http://fortunaweb.com.ar/2013-03-29-119045-carlos-molinari-del-barrio-cerrado-a-las-viviendas-sociales/ }}</ref><ref name=avion>{{cite web| title =Molinari, el empresario K que quiere los aviones| work =El Observador| date =Nov 10, 2012| url = http://www.elobservador.com.uy/noticia/234540/molinari-el-empresario-k-que-quiere-los-aviones/}}</ref>
Molinari described himself in 2011 during a brief foray into electoral politics as “a businessman who believes in social justice,<ref name=avion/>”. He is a longtime associate of the Kirchner family and a key figure in the so-called K money trail, the 2013 political scandal centering on acts of embezzlement and money laundering by persons connected to the presidential administrations of [[Nestor Kirchner]] and [[Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner]].
==Career== Molinari has been described as the “son of a trade unionist” and as being “of humble origins.”<ref name=avion/>
He is president of Real Estate Investments (REI) Sociedad Fiduciaria, which manages real estate in Argentina, including the 68-hectare Hudson Park in Berazategui.<ref name=elentr>{{cite web| title =Millonario K ligado a Concordia | work =El Entrerios| date =May 10, 2013| url = http://www.elentrerios.com/politica/millonario-k-ligado-a-concordia.htm}}</ref> Hudson Park, “an exclusive gated community,” has been described as Molinari’s “beloved child.” It includes houses, a condo-hotel, and shops, all built at an investment of around $30 million.”<ref name=fortuna/>
In the U.S., Molinari is the President of Global Development Consultant Inc., based in Miami, Florida, and registered in 2009. He is also a Managing Member of Adg Group Holdings, LLC; The New Langford, LLC.; and La Bahia, LLC.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wysk.com/index/florida/miami/8dyyan3/global-development-consultant-inc/profile |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517120341/http://www.wysk.com/index/florida/miami/8dyyan3/global-development-consultant-inc/profile |archivedate=2014-05-17 |df= }}</ref> In addition, he has served as an officer of several now-inactive U.S. entities, such as the Americas Real Estate Investments Inc., American Condo Hotel Group, Miami Wolf Soccer Team Inc., MDJ Housing Industries Corp., Argentinian Construction Group LLC, and National Argentine American Foundation, Inc.<ref>https://opencorporates.com/officers/8100171</ref><ref>http://www.bizapedia.com/people/CARLOS-MOLINARI.html</ref>
In addition to Hudson Park, Molinari has constructed a hotel-condominium development, La Aldea de Pilar, and a project called “La Mansión,” a complex of “VIP towers” in the historical district of Quilmes. Noting that all three of these projects are located in areas governed by Kirchernist politicians, a journalist for Perfil observed that “politics often helps one find more and better opportunities.”<ref name=perfil/>
In March 2013 Molinari was described as being currently engaged in “developing a condo-hotel in a historic downtown building” in “most Latin American cities.” At the time, he was planning to initiate such projects shortly in Punta del Este, Pilar, Bernal, Mar del Plata, and Rosario.<ref name=fortuna/>
Molinari has built low-cost housing in [[Haiti]] out of containers. Molinari explained that this was an ecologically positive activity, given that there are “a lot of unused containers” in ports and that their rusting “causes severe environmental pollution problems.... By using this material, we are recovering a toxic waste.”<ref name=fortuna/>
Molinari was described in 2013 as a gifted analyst of the real-estate market, who in a 2004 conversation with [[Tomás Pedro Regalado|Tomás Regalado]], later elected mayor of Miami, predicted the mortgage crisis “when nobody was talking about anything but the euphoria of large investments.”<ref name=fortuna/>
It was reported in March 2013 that Molinari had “recently” started work on a 40-hectare Public Industrial Park in Canelones, [[Uruguay]], an investment of $120 million.<ref name=fortuna/>
Molinari is a director or shareholder of such Argentinian firms as Land Developer SA, and Sharks Sports SA, ADG Argentinian Developer Group SA, among others.<ref name=eeuu>{{cite web| last =Santoro| first =Daniel| title =Caso Báez: uno de los involucrados, en problemas con la Justicia de EE.UU.| work =Clarin| date =Nov 7, 2013| url = http://www.clarin.com/politica/Caso-Baez-involucrados-Justicia-EEUU_0_953904630.html}}</ref>
In October 2012, it was reported that Molinari wanted “to create a new airline in forty-five days.” He was in negotiations to buy seven aircraft from the defunct Uruguayan airline Pluna, which was in bankruptcy proceedings, and re-employ most of its 700 former employees. He presented Homero Guerrero, secretary to the Uruguayan president, with a plan to purchase the aircraft for close to $130 million and form a Uruguayan-based airline called Alas Sudamericanas, at an initial total investment of $190 million, that would be in the air within 45 days. He even met with President Mujica of Uruguay. But the plan did not work out. Molinari complained that the issue had been “politicized.” He said, however, that he was carrying out feasibility studies aimed at the creation of his own Uruguayan airline, explaining that Uruguay ”is a strategic point in Latin America.”<ref name=fortuna/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://prensa.cancilleria.gov.ar/noticia.php?id%3D26627639 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517124401/http://prensa.cancilleria.gov.ar/noticia.php?id=26627639 |archivedate=2014-05-17 |df= }}</ref>
Molinari is a founding member of the regional business platform Developers & Builders Alliance (DBA), which has offices in the U.S. and throughout Latin America.<ref name=urug>{{cite web| last =Ladra| first =Antonio| title =Uruguay en la ruta del dinero de los K| work =El Contecer| date =Apr 16, 2013| url = http://www.elacontecer.com.uy/18819-uruguay-en-la-ruta-del-dinero-de-los-k.html}}</ref>
==Political activities== In 2011, Molinari ran as deputy when his friend [[Mario Ishii]] challenged the candidacy of [[Daniel Scioli]] for re-election as governor of the Buenos Aires province. "We are a possible alternative to the management of the current provincial leader,” Molinari told an interviewer. “We are able to see an alternative for the people of Buenos Aires with my practicality and with the ideological capacity of Mario Ishii.” Ishii and Molinari failed to win, despite a reported expenditure by Molinari of 6 million pesos.<ref name=urug/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elembudo.tv/politica/40-politica/1171-la-extrana-historia-de-carlos-molinari-ex-companero-de-formula-de-mario-ishii.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517121118/http://www.elembudo.tv/politica/40-politica/1171-la-extrana-historia-de-carlos-molinari-ex-companero-de-formula-de-mario-ishii.html |archivedate=2014-05-17 |df= }}</ref><ref>http://www.latecla.info/3/nota_1.php?noticia_id=46948</ref>
===Obama connection=== Molinari is friendly with Miami businessman [[Freddy Balsera]], who led the [[Barack Obama]] campaign’s outreach effort to Latinos and is head of the Hispanic Council of the Democratic Party in the U.S. Together, Molinari and Balsera have been involved together in a business venture involving “social housing.”<ref name=avion/><ref name=urug/>
Molinari visited the White House in 2010 and contributed financially to the reelection campaign of President Obama in 2010.<ref name=eeuu/> He also attended a 2010 dinner in Miami in support of Obama at the mansion of Gloria and Emilio Estefan, where he spoke to President Obama.<ref name=elentr/> He has also donated to the [[Democratic Party PAC ActBlue]].<ref>http://www.city-data.com/elec2/10/elec-MIAMI-FL-10-part3.html</ref>
===K money trail scandal=== {{Main|The K money trail}} The scandal erupted as a result of the April 14, 2013, episode of the investigative journalism program ''Periodismo para todos (Journalism for All)'', hosted by [[Jorge Lanata]]. The episode, entitled “The K money trail,” included hidden-camera footage on which [[Leonardo Fariña]], the husband of famous model [[Karina Jelinek]], described in detail the financial maneuvers whereby [[Lázaro Báez]], a businessman close to the Kirchners, managed to transfer about 55 million euros from Argentina to [[Switzerland]]. Fariña had aided in this money-laundering operation, and it was established that the link between Báez and Fariña was Molinari, who was described as the “protector” of Fariña, a childhood friend of his son Martin.<ref name=urug/>
Appearing on the [[Jorge Rial]] radio program later in April, Molinari maintained that he had no involvement in money-laundering; that he had never met Báez; that he had met Fariña in late 2010, when Fariña had approached him with the idea of starting a luxury-car rental agency; and that he had known Federico Elaskar since the latter was 15 years old and a friend of his son, living in the same apartment building as the Molinaris, but that he had never done business with him.<ref>http://www.clarin.com/politica/Molinari-Elaskar-conozco-amigo-hijo_0_906509541.html</ref><ref>http://www.perfil.com/politica/Hablo-Carlos-Molinari-el-multimillonario-jefe-de-Leo-Faria-20130423-0031.html</ref><ref>http://www.clarin.com/politica/Empresario-blanquear-contactos-Elaskar-Farina_0_907109322.html</ref> “I'm a businessman,” Molinari said. “I do business.”<ref>http://www.elliberal.com.ar/ampliada.php?ID=87665</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.urgente24.com/213356-la-version-de-molinari-el-millonario-protector-de-farina?pagination%3Dshow |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517122549/http://www.urgente24.com/213356-la-version-de-molinari-el-millonario-protector-de-farina?pagination=show |archivedate=2014-05-17 |df= }}</ref><ref>http://www.lapoliticaonline.com/nota/68847/</ref>
In late April 2013, Molinari was violently assaulted by five men in the Palermo section of Buenos Aires who took several items from him, including his Audi A7 truck, which was found abandoned shortly thereafter.<ref>http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1576136-asaltan-y-golpean-al-empresario-carlos-molinari</ref> It was suggested that the beating and robbery of Molinari were the work of “mobsters” sending a “message.”<ref name=eeuu/>
[[Elisa Carrió]], a member of the Argentinian parliament, described Fariña in April 2013 as being “protected” by Molinari.<ref>http://tn.com.ar/politica/carrio-%E2%80%9Ctodo-lo-que-dice-farina-tiene-respaldo-documental%E2%80%9D_383507</ref>
Fariña testified in June 2013 that he was an auditor for Austral Construcciones, a firm owned by Báez, and that he worked for Molinari, who paid him a monthly salary of 70,000 pesos.<ref>http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1590774-leonardo-farina-declaro-ante-la-justicia-y-admitio-que-conoce-a-lazaro-baez</ref> Also in June 2013, Maximiliano Acosta told a court that Molinari and his son Mathias had presented themselves to him as project developers and as representatives of Báez and his son.<ref>http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1589050-el-testigo-de-boda-de-farina-complico-a-perez-gadin</ref>
It was reported in July 2013 that Molinari was “in trouble” in the U.S. courts. He was sought in connection with a Miami trial, ''Carlos Germán Díaz vs Global Development Consultant Inc'', in which he was named as a defendant, and with a New York case, brought by Kenneth Welt against Diego Molinari, Deborah Batista, and Amadeo Molinari of [[Moll Systems Corporation]], that involved a payment to a Panamanian firm, [[Tensho Media]].<ref name=eeuu/><ref>http://dockets.justia.com/docket/florida/flsdce/1:2013cv20729/416235</ref>
In September 2013, federal judge Sebastián Casanello ordered a raid on Molinari’s firm Rei Fiduciaria, in order to determine the legitimacy of Fariña’s claim that his lavish lifestyle could be accounted for by his income from Rei Fudiciaria.<ref>http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1616457-caso-baez-allanan-una-firma-y-carrio-pide-interpelar-a-timerman</ref>
===Relations with Fariña=== Molinari has been described as the man who “invented” the husband of Karina Jelinek, “since it was he who gave her the famous Ferrari” and paid for the couple’s wedding. Molinari said that Fariña had been recommended to him by a lawyer in La Plata. “He proposed to me the business of high-end car rental, and bought five cars, some on behalf of the company and others in my name,” said Molinari. “The idea was good, because they were cars that were not in Argentina.” At that time Fariña had not yet become involved with Jelinek, and “seemed to be a person with an ordinary life.” Molinari said he paid Fariña “a per diem of six thousand dollars and also had a stake in the [car-rental] company.” After Fariña and Jelinek became a couple, Molinari disliked the negative press that the couple generated and encouraged Fariña to lower his profile and to clarify that his car was company-owned and that he was not a millionaire. Molinari said he had paid for Fariña’s and Jelinek’s wedding, a total outlay of 480,000 pesos, in order to promote the car-rental firm, some of whose wares were on display at the wedding.<ref>http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1591140-farina-dejo-muchas-dudas-ante-el-juez</ref><ref>http://lasombradelespectaculo.wordpress.com/2013/04/25/escandalo-farina-rossi-carlos-molinari-el-hombre-que-invento-al-empresario/</ref>
Elaskar testified that he knew Fariña through Molinari’s son Matías. The elder Molinari, said Elaskar, had given his wife an Audi as a wedding gift.<ref>http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1590825-caso-baez-farina-y-elaskar-acusaron-a-lanata-ante-el-juez</ref>
==Personal life== Molinari has five sons.<ref>http://www.perfil.com/politica/Molinari-el-magnate-con-lazos-politicos-detras-del-escandalo-20130421-0001.html</ref> He had a son with Lucrecia Silva, a former ballet dancer and former TV host and the current owner of a baby-clothing store in Concordia, in which Molinari reportedly invested. Their son’s christening party was held at Club Progreso in 2012.<ref name=elentr/>
Molinari’s luxurious house in Pilar, Buenos Aires, was the subject of a feature in the magazine ''Caras'' in 2011.<ref>http://www.urgente24.com/12574-molinari-como-jelinek-en-caras-nunca-trabaje-por-diner{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Performing artist [[Marixa Balli]] stated in 2013 that Molinari had been her CD producer and lover in Miami many years earlier.<ref>http://www.clarin.com/politica/Ruta_del_dinero_K-Marixa_Balli-gastos-Carlos_Molinari-Leonarido_Farina_0_907109544.html</ref> She also said that he had paid for her most recent trip to Miami.<ref name=eeuu/>

{{unreferenced|date=March 2017}} {{infobox organization |name=Community Business Development Corporation (CBDC) |type=Not-for-profit, Financial services, Business Counsulting |founded = Guysborough, Nova Scotia, Canada, 1975 | website = [http://www.cbdc.ca/ CBDC Website] | leader_title = COO | leader_name = Basil Ryan | leader_title2 = CFO | leader_name2 = Dawn Grant }} The '''Community Business Development Corporation''' (CBDC) (French: La Corporation de développement communautaire) is a federal and provincially funded [[Nonprofit organization|not-for-profit organization]]. CBDCs assist in the creation of small businesses and in the expansion and modernization of existing small businesses by providing financial and technical services to entrepreneurs.
The organisation was founded in the 1970s and currently holds 41 offices throughout Atlantic Canada. The 41 offices are autonomous corporations but each work with their respective Provincial Association office. The Provincial Association offices are located in; Alberton, PEI; Elmsdale, NS; Mount Pearl, NL; and Bathurst, NB. These 4 offices work with the Atlantic Association of CBDCs to constantly improve the services offered by the CBDC network. The CBDCs are a member of the [[Community Futures|Community Futures Network of Canada]].
== Operating Structure == [[File:NLCBDC.jpg|thumb|300x300px|Managing Director Roseanne Leonard of the NL Association of CBDCs presents donation to the Ewings Cancer Foundation of Canada]] '''CBDCs''' operate under the guidance of a local [[Board of directors|Board of Directors]].[[Community business development corporation#cite note-Governance-2|<sup>[2]</sup>]] The Board of Directors is representative of the area served by the '''CBDC,''' and all members of the board are community business leaders and volunteers. This organizational structure permits the '''CBDC''' to play a direct and active role in employment development within their [[jurisdiction]]. The Board of Directors is complemented by a professional staff, varying in size depending on the level of activity within the region served and resources made available to it by the [[Government of Canada]]. '''CBDCs''' act as a delivery agent for several governmental financing programs for small business. They have options available to help individuals establish a new business, expand an existing one, or to stabilize/modernize their current business.
== Services == '''CBDC''' offers financial assistance in the form of loans, loan guarantees and equity financing to existing and aspiring entrepreneurs. It puts a high priority to the advisory role of its mandate by focusing on providing business counselling and advice to its clients. '''CBDC''' provides entrepreneurship development and training to individuals and small business owners. It can also advocate on behalf of its clients to other lending establishments or regulatory agencies. Typically '''CBDC''' targets its services to entrepreneurs who require customized financing not available from traditional sources.
Some of the custom financing options offered include but are not limited to; CBDC Social Enterprise Loan, CBDC First-Time Entrepreneur Loan, CBDC General Business Loan, CBDC Youth Loan, CBDC Innovation Loan, Self Employment Assistance Program and the Consultant Advisory Services Program.[[File:CBDC Banners.jpg|thumb|300x300px|Pop-up banners highlighting CBDC services]]
==Jurisdiction== The '''CBDCs''' are dedicated to the development of small business and job creation and enhancement in rural Atlantic Canada. CBDCs are subject to [[Treasury Board of Canada]] regulations.

{{Redirect|Senior Project|the 2014 film|Senior Project (film)}} {{refimprove|date=May 2015}} {{tone|date=May 2015}} A '''culminating project''' (also known as a '''senior project''', '''grad project''' or '''exit project'''), is a project that challenges high school seniors to demonstrate their academic knowledge in an experiential way (in most cases). According to the US Dept of Education<ref>http://www.ed.gov/policy/elsec/leg/esea02/index.html</ref> State Education Boards typically allow individual [[school district]]s to customize the project, based on basic state guidelines.
== Confusion about the culminating project ==
People reporting on the culminating project sometimes confuse the terminology with the state [[high school exit exam]]. The state exit exam is a written exam that usually tests student’s math, reading, writing, and science skills, whereas the culminating project is a required project that is usually a learning experience based on a topic chosen by the student. The project is mandatory in order to graduate.
== Purpose == The purpose of the project is to increase both teaching and learning. High school graduation standards have declined for several decades. [[Education reform|School reform]] or the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001<ref>http://www.ed.gov/parents/academic/involve/nclbguide/parentsguide.pdf</ref> is a way to bring value back to the high school diploma as well as support students as they go out into the world prepared for college, a job, the military, entrepreneurship, internship, or whatever path students decide to follow once they graduate.
== Why a project is required == The requirement is an effort to increase the education standards. As [[college admissions]] and the workplace require more from their recruits, nationwide high schools must also.
In an effort to be clear, it is restated that the culminating project is not required by all schools. Again, parents and guardians would have to check with the student’s school official website for graduation requirements.
However, for students that are required to complete a culminating project, this is a chance for the student to explore a topic of personal interest. The project provides an opportunity that student may not have otherwise. By completing the project, students have a [[real life experience]] that can help them in their next adventure in life (college, job, entrepreneurship, military, internship, etc.).
Students gain a number of important skills by participating in the process such as, * Leadership * Communication * Project management * [[Time management]] * Group skills * Negotiation skills * Meeting deadlines * Conflict management * [[Public speaking]] * Presentation skills * [[Self motivation]]
== Kinds of projects == The high school graduation culminating project format varies from state to state and even school to school within the same state. Parents and guardians will have to check with their students specific school for their requirements. Typically the project consists of choosing a topic of interest, writing a [[Academic publishing|research paper]] on that topic, having an experience directly related to the topic, keeping a journal of artifacts demonstrating your work, followed by the final step which is a presentation (US Dept of Education).
The student usually presents the project to a panel consisting of 2-5 people typically made up of teachers, community members, faculty, and staff. However, some schools have student present to a panel of their peers. Schools and school districts have total discretion to format the process in a way that works best for their students and their school culture.
In some cases, students complete a project on their own with the support of a mentor from their community. Some schools allow group projects and [[Presentation of a group|group presentation]]. For example, it would not be uncommon for the leadership class of a school to raise funds to build a school in Africa. Other requirements include a mandatory social/community aspect related to the project which means the high school graduation project has to benefit someone other than the student.

'''Downtown Los Angeles''' ('''DTLA''') is the [[central business district]] of [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], as well as a diverse [[neighborhood|residential neighborhood]] of some 58,000 people. A 2013 study found that the district is home to over 500,000 jobs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Downtown LA Demographic Study 2013|url=http://www.downtownla.com/survey-2013-results.asp|accessdate=3 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151027004505/http://www.downtownla.com/survey-2013-results.asp|archivedate=27 October 2015|website=DowntownLA}}</ref> It is also part of [[Central Los Angeles]].
A heritage of the city's founding in 1781, Downtown Los Angeles today is composed of different areas ranging from a [[fashion]] district to [[Skid Row, Los Angeles|Skid Row]]. It is the hub for the city's [[Los Angeles Metro Rail|urban rail transit system]] and the [[Metrolink (California)|Metrolink]] commuter rail system for Southern California.
Banks, [[department stores]], and [[movie palaces]] at one time drew residents and visitors into the area, but the district declined economically and suffered a downturn for decades until its recent renaissance starting in the early 2000s. Old buildings are being modified for new uses, and skyscrapers have been built.
Downtown Los Angeles is known for its government buildings, parks, theaters, and other public places.
==History== {{refimprove section| date=May 2013}} {{ further|History of Los Angeles }}
===Early years=== The earliest known settlements in the area of what is now Downtown Los Angeles was by the [[Tongva people|Tongva]], a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] people. Later European settlement arrived after Father [[Juan Crespí]], a Spanish missionary charged with exploring sites for [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] [[Spanish missions in California|missions in California]], noted in 1769 that the region had "all the requisites for a large settlement."<ref>[http://www.usc.edu/libraries/archives/la/historic/crespi.html FATHER CRESPI IN LOS ANGELES, USC] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090707155441/http://www.usc.edu/libraries/archives/la/historic/crespi.html |date=July 7, 2009 }}</ref> On September 4, 1781, the city was founded by a group of settlers who trekked north from present-day Mexico.
Land speculation increased in the 1880s, which saw the population of the city explode from 11,000 in 1880 to nearly 100,000 by 1896.<ref>[http://www.downtownla.com/5_05_downtownHistory.asp Downtown History, Downtown Center Business Improvement District] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090804025547/http://www.downtownla.com/5_05_downtownHistory.asp |date=August 4, 2009 }}</ref> Infrastructure enhancements and the laying of a street grid eventually brought development south of the original settlement into what is today the [[Civic Center, Los Angeles|Civic Center]] and [[Historic Core, Los Angeles|Historic Core]] neighborhoods.
===Downtown's golden age=== By 1920, the city's private and municipal rail lines were the most far-flung and most comprehensive in the world in mileage, even besting that of [[New York City]]. By this time, a steady influx of residents and aggressive land developers had transformed the city into a large metropolitan area, with DTLA at its center. Rail lines connected four counties with over {{convert|1100|mi|km|sp=us}} of track.<ref>[http://www.westworld.com/~elson/larail/PE/tunnel.html Westworld. 2000] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100503130518/http://www.westworld.com/~elson/larail/PE/tunnel.html |date=May 3, 2010 }}</ref>
During the early part of the 20th century, banking institutions clustered around South Spring Street, forming the [[Spring Street Financial District]]. Sometimes referred to as the "[[Wall Street of the West]],"<ref>"[http://articles.latimes.com/2000/jun/11/local/me-39908 Wall Street of the West Had Its Peaks, Crashes]", ''Los Angeles Times''.</ref> the district held corporate headquarters for financial institutions including [[Bank of America]], [[Farmers and Merchants Bank of Los Angeles|Farmers and Merchants Bank]], the [[Crocker National Bank]], California Bank & Trust, and International Savings & Exchange Bank. The [[Pacific Exchange|Los Angeles Stock Exchange]] was also located on the corridor from 1929 until 1986 before moving into a new building across the [[Interstate 110 (California)|Harbor (110) Freeway]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publicartinla.com/Downtown/Broadway/stock_exchange.html |title=Salvatore Cartaino Scarpitta, Los Angeles Stock Exchange, bas reliefs |publisher=Publicartinla.com |date=1929-10-29 |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref>
Commercial growth brought with it hotel construction—during this time period several grand hotels, the Alexandria (1906), the Rosslyn (1911), and the [[Millennium Biltmore Hotel|Biltmore]] (1923), were erected — and also the need for venues to entertain the growing population of Los Angeles. [[Broadway Theater and Commercial District|Broadway]] became the nightlife, shopping and entertainment district of the city, with over a dozen theater and movie palaces built before 1932.
Department stores also opened flagship stores downtown, including [[The Broadway]], Hamburger & Sons, [[May Department Stores|May Company]], [[JW Robinson's]], and [[Bullock's]], serving a wealthy residential population in the [[Bunker Hill, Los Angeles|Bunker Hill]] neighborhood. Numerous specialty stores also flourished including those in the jewelry business which gave rise to the Downtown Jewelry District. Among these early jewelers included the Laykin Diamond Company (later becoming Laykin et Cie [http://www.laykinetcie.com]) and [[Harry Winston]] & Co., both of which found their beginnings in the [[Hotel Alexandria]] at Fifth and Spring streets.
The [[Los Angeles Union Station|Los Angeles Union Passenger Terminal]] (Union Station) opened in May 1939, unifying passenger service among various local, regional, and long-distance passenger trains. It was built on a grand scale and would be one of the "last of the great railway stations" built in the United States.
===Decline and redevelopment=== [[File:Angels flight los angeles.jpg|thumb|220px|[[Angels Flight]], November 2008]] Following [[World War II]], [[suburbanization]], the development of the Los Angeles freeway network, and increased automobile ownership led to decreased investment downtown. Many corporate headquarters slowly dispersed to new suburbs or fell to mergers and acquisitions. The once-wealthy [[Bunker Hill, Los Angeles|Bunker Hill]] neighborhood became a haven for low-income renters, its stately Victorian mansions turned into [[flophouse]]s.
From about 1930 onward, numerous very old and historic buildings in the plaza area were demolished to make way for street-level parking lots, the high demand for parking making this more profitable than any other option that might have allowed preservation. The drastic reduction in the number of residents in the area further reduced the viability of streetfront businesses that would be able to attract pedestrians. For most Angelenos, downtown became a drive-in, drive-out destination.
In an effort to combat [[Urban decay|blight]] and lure businesses back downtown, the city's [[Community redevelopment agency|Community Redevelopment Agency]] undertook the [[Bunker Hill Redevelopment Project]] in 1955, a massive clearance project that leveled homes and cleared land for future commercial skyscraper development. This period saw the clearing and upzoning of the entire neighborhood, as well as the shuttering of the [[Angels Flight]] funicular railway in 1969. Angels Flight resumed operation in 1996 for a period of five years, shutting down once again after a fatal accident in 2001. On March 15, 2010, the railway once again opened for passenger service following extensive upgrades to brake and safety systems.
With [[Class A office space]] becoming available on Bunker Hill, many of DTLA's remaining financial corporations moved to the newer buildings, leaving the former [[Spring Street Financial District]] devoid of tenants above ground floor. Following the corporate headquarters' moving six blocks west, the large department stores on Broadway shuttered, culminating in the 1980s.
However, the Broadway theaters saw much use as Spanish-language movie houses during this time, beginning with the conversion of the [[Million Dollar Theater]] in the 1950s to a Spanish-language theater.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laconservancy.org/remaining/remaining_theatres08.php4#million |title=Last Remaining Seats |publisher=Laconservancy.org |date= |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref>
===Recent years=== [[File:Wilshire Grand.jpg|thumb|220px|The [[Wilshire Grand Center]] in Downtown LA is the tallest building in the U.S. west of the [[Mississippi River]] at ({{convert|1099|ft|m|sp=us|disp=or}}). It is also currently the [[List of tallest buildings in California|tallest building in the state of California]].]] [[File:Los-Angeles-Civic-Center-and-Union-Station-Aerial-view-from-south-August-2014.jpg|thumb|220px|Aerial view in 2014]] [[File:Union Station in Downtown Los Angeles.jpg|thumb|220px|[[Los Angeles Union Station]]]] In mid-2013, downtown was noted as "a neighborhood with an increasingly [[Hip (slang)|hip]] and [[:wikt:well-heeled|well-heeled]] residential population."<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/business/money/la-fi-mo-whole-foods-downtown-20130731,0,2826238.story David Pierson, "Whole Foods to Open Downtown L.A. Store in 2015," ''Los Angeles Times,'' July 31, 2013]</ref>
Because of the downtown area's office market's migration west to Bunker Hill and the [[Financial District, Los Angeles|Financial District]], many historic office buildings have been left intact, simply used for storage or remaining empty during recent decades. In 1999, the [[Los Angeles City Council]] passed an [[adaptive reuse]] [[Local ordinance|ordinance]], making it easier for developers to convert outmoded, vacant office and commercial buildings into [[loft apartment|renovated lofts]] and luxury apartment and condo complexes.
As of early 2009, 14,561 residential units<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.downtownla.com/pdfs/econ_residential/1Q09HousingBook.pdf|title=Downtown LA - Page not found...|website=www.downtownla.com}}</ref> have been created under the adaptive reuse ordinance, leading to an increase in the residential population. With 28,878 residents in 2006<ref name=DiMassa01>Cara Mia DiMassa, "[http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-downtown21feb21,0,4218500.story Downtown L.A. has gained people but lost jobs, report says]", ''Los Angeles Times,'' February 21, 2007.</ref> and 39,537 in 2008,<ref name="downtownla1">[http://www.downtownla.com/survey/2011/Downtown-LA-Demographic-Study-2011.pdf] DowntownLA.com demographic study</ref> a 36.9% increase, Downtown Los Angeles is seeing new life and investment.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-main-street11-2009jun11,0,4047200.story | work=Los Angeles Times | date=2009-06-11 | title=Ordinance brings new life into downtown L.A.'s Main Street}}</ref>
*[[Staples Center]], which opened in 1999, has contributed immensely to the revitalization plans, adding 250 events and nearly 4 million visitors per year to the neighborhood.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aegworldwide.com/01_venues/staples_center.php |title=Facilities, STAPLES Center |publisher=AEG Worldwide |date= |accessdate=2009-06-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828062613/http://aegworldwide.com/01_venues/staples_center.php |archivedate=2008-08-28 |df= }}</ref> Since the opening of the Staples Center, the adjacent [[L.A. Live]] complex was completed, which includes the [[Nokia Theatre L.A. Live|Microsoft Theatre]] and the [[The Grammy Museum|Grammy Museum]]. *[[Los Angeles County Metro Rail]], a rail transit network centered on the downtown area, facilitates access to the city center, especially from the congested West Side. *[[Real estate developer]]s and investors planned a $1.8 billion revitalization project along Grand Avenue, which included the development of [[Grand Park]], a large city park,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/may/27/worlddispatch.usa |title=Downtown looks up: Dan Glaister reports on ambitious plans to create a brighter, better and shinier heart of LA |last=Glaister |first=Dan |date=27 May 2005 |work=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=19 July 2012 |location=London}}</ref> and the construction of major city landmarks, including the [[Frank Gehry]]-designed [[Walt Disney Concert Hall]] and contemporary art museum [[The Broad]], which opened in 2015. *On August 7, 2007, the [[Los Angeles City Council]] approved sweeping changes in zoning and development rules for the downtown area.<ref name=LAT080807>Sharon Bernstein and David Pierson, "[http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-downtown8aug08,0,5462749,full.story L.A. moves toward more N.Y-style downtown]", ''Los Angeles Times,'' August 8, 2007.</ref> Strongly advocated by Mayor [[Antonio Villaraigosa]], the changes allow larger and denser developments downtown; developers who reserve 15% of their units for low-income residents are now exempt from some open-space requirements and can make their buildings 35% larger than current zoning codes allow.<ref name="LAT080807"/> *In 2009 [[Bottega Louie]] opened on the first floor of the historic [[Brockman Building]] on [[Grand Avenue (Los Angeles)|Grand Avenue]] and Seventh Street. It contributed to the revitalization of DTLA by creating Restaurant Row, which has since brought numerous new restaurants and retail shops to the area.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ladowntownnews.com/news/the-downtowners-of-distinction/article_1b311095-358e-5d39-ab5b-351f6dcb9c1a.html|title=The Downtowners of Distinction|first=Jon |last=Regardie|date= February 18, 2011|work=[[Los Angeles Downtown News]]|access-date=26 March 2016}}</ref> In 2012, the upper 11 floors of the Brockman Building were bought with the intention of being sold as luxury lofts.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/apr/16/business/la-fi-mo-brockman-lofts-20120413 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Roger | last=Vincent | title=New owners turning Brockman Building into apartments | date=2012-04-16}}</ref> *In October 2015, an outdoor lifestyle center, [[The Bloc Los Angeles]], replaced the old enclosed Macy's Plaza.
Multiple Olympic and Paralympic events will be held in DTLA during the [[2028 Summer Olympics]] and [[Paralympics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://la24-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/assets/pdf/LA2024-canditature-part2_english.pdf |title=Assets |website=la24-prod.s3.amazonaws.com |format=PDF}}</ref>
==Geography== {{wide image|Los Angeles downtown sunset cityscape.jpg|1680px|align-cap=center|Downtown skyline during sunset as seen from [[Griffith Observatory]], October 2006.}}
Downtown Los Angeles is flanked by [[Echo Park, Los Angeles|Echo Park]] to the north and northwest, [[Chinatown, Los Angeles|Chinatown]] to the northeast, [[Boyle Heights]] to the east, [[Vernon, California|Vernon]] to the south, [[Historic South Central]] and [[University Park, Los Angeles|University Park]] to the southwest, and [[Pico-Union]] and [[Westlake, Los Angeles|Westlake]] to the west.<ref name=MappingLACentralLA>[http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/region/central-la/] "Central L.A.," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''</ref><ref name=MappingLADowntown>[http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/neighborhood/downtown] "Downtown," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''</ref><ref name=ThomasGuideDowntownLA>''The Thomas Guide,'' 2006, pages 634 and 674</ref>
Downtown is bounded on the northeast by [[Cesar Chavez Avenue]], on the east by the [[Los Angeles River]], on the south by the Los Angeles [[city limits|city line]] with Vernon, on the southwest by East [[Washington Boulevard (Los Angeles)|Washington Boulevard]] and on the west by the [[Interstate 110 and State Route 110 (California)|110 Freeway]] or Beaudry Avenue, including the entire [[Four Level Interchange]] with [[California 101#Los Angeles to Ventura|Highway 101]].<ref name=MappingLADowntown/><ref name=ThomasGuideDowntownLA/>
===Districts=== Within the neighborhood are included these smaller areas: {{Div col}} *[[Arts District, Los Angeles|Arts District]]<ref>[http://discoverlosangeles.com 2012-2013 Official Visitors Map], Los Angeles Tourism & Convention Board, 2012</ref> *[[Bunker Hill, Los Angeles|Bunker Hill]]<ref name=MappingLADowntown/> *[[Skid Row, Los Angeles|Skid Row]]<ref name=MappingLADowntown/> *[[Civic Center, Los Angeles|Civic Center]]<ref name=MappingLADowntown/> *[[Fashion District, Los Angeles|Fashion District]]<ref name=MappingLADowntown/> *[[Financial District, Los Angeles|Financial District]] *[[Gallery Row, Los Angeles|Gallery Row]] *[[Historic Core]] *[[Industrial District, Los Angeles|Industrial District]]<ref name=MappingLADowntown/> *[[Jewelry District, Los Angeles|Jewelry District]]<ref name=MappingLADowntown/> *[[Little Tokyo, Los Angeles|Little Tokyo]]<ref name=MappingLADowntown/> *[[Old Bank District, Los Angeles|Old Bank District]]<ref name=MappingLADowntown/> *[[South Park (Downtown Los Angeles)|South Park]]<ref name=MappingLADowntown/> *[[Toy District, Los Angeles|Toy District]] *[[Wholesale District, Los Angeles|Wholesale District or Warehouse District]] {{div col end}}
==Population== [[File:Los Angeles Skyline at Night.jpg|thumb|220px|Downtown Los Angeles at night]] [[File:OrpheumTheatreMarquee.jpg|thumb|220px|The [[Orpheum Theatre (Los Angeles, California)|Orpheum Theatre]], 2007]] [[File:St Vincent Court - Downtown Los Angeles 03.jpg|thumb|St Vincent Court in 2017. European-style decorations date to 1957.]] The 2000 U.S. census found that just 27,849 residents lived in the 5.84 square miles of downtown—or 4,770 people per square mile, among the lowest densities for the city of Los Angeles but about average for the county. The [[Southern California Association of Governments]] estimates that downtown's daytime population is 207,440.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://maps.latimes.com/neighborhoods/neighborhood/downtown/|title=Downtown|website=Mapping L.A.}}</ref> The population increased to 34,811 by 2008, according to city estimates. As of 2014, the population of the district had grown to 52,400 residents, and 5200 residential units were under construction.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wowtapka|first1=Dawn|title=In Downtown LA, a Housing Revival|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304281004579220210670242326|accessdate=July 13, 2014|agency=Wall Street Journal|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=November 26, 2013}}</ref> The median age for residents was 39, considered old for the city and [[Los Angeles County|the county]].<ref name=MappingLADowntown/>
Downtown Los Angeles is almost evenly balanced among the four major racial and ethnic groups — [[Asian Americans]] (23%), [[African Americans]] (22%), [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Latinos]] (25%) and [[non-Hispanic whites]] (26%) — according to an analysis of 2010 census data made by [[Loyola Marymount University]] researchers.<ref>{{cite news|last=Trounson|first=Rebecca|title=A multicultural moment: Downtown L.A.'s population evenly split|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/04/multicultural-moment-downtown-la.html|accessdate=April 13, 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=April 12, 2012}}</ref>
A study of the 2000 census showed that downtown was the second–most diverse neighborhood in Los Angeles, its [[diversity index]] being 0.743, outrated only by [[Mid-Wilshire]].<ref>[http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/diversity/neighborhood/list/#downtown] "Diversity," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''</ref> The ethnic breakdown in 2000 was [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Latinos]], 36.7%; [[African Americans|blacks]], 22.3%; [[Asian Americans|Asians]], 21.3%; [[Non-Hispanic whites|whites]], 16.2%, and others, 3.5%. Mexico (44.7%) and Korea (17%) were the most common places of birth for the 41.9% of the residents who were born abroad, about the same ratio as in the city as a whole.<ref name=MappingLADowntown/>
The median household income in 2008 dollars was $15,003, considered low for both the city and the county. The percentage of households earning $20,000 or less (57.4%) was the highest in Los Angeles County, followed by University Park (56.6%) and Chinatown (53.6%). The average household size of 1.6 people was relatively low. Renters occupied 93.4% of the housing units, and home or apartment owners the rest.<ref name=MappingLADowntown/><ref>[http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/income/20-or-less/neighborhood/list] "$20,000 or less," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''</ref>
In 2000, there were 2,400 military veterans living downtown, or 9.7% of the population, considered a high rate for the city but average for the county overall.<ref name=MappingLADowntown/>
In 2013, a study by Downtown Center Business Improvement District showed that of the 52,400 people resided in Downtown Los Angeles. The demographic breakdown was 52.7% Caucasian, 20.1% Asian, 17.0% Latino, and 6.2% African-American; 52.9% female, 47.1% male; and 74.8% of residents were between the ages of 23-44.The median age for residents was 34. The median household income was $98,700. The median household size was 1.8. In terms of educational attainment, 80.1% of residents had completed at least 4 years of college. The study was a self-selecting sample of 8,841 respondents across the DTLA area. It was not a "census" but rather a comprehensive survey of Downtown LA consumers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.downtownla.com/survey/2013/results/DTLA-Demo-Study-2013.pdf|title=Downtown LA - Page not found...|website=www.downtownla.com}}</ref>
An additional study by the Downtown Center Business Improvement District showed that by 2017 the population has reached 67,324 <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.downtownla.com/images/reports/BID_MarketReport2017.Q8.Web.pdf |title=Market report |website=www.downtownla.com |format=PDF}}</ref>
==Public transportation== ===Local and regional service=== [[File:Los Angeles County Metro Rail and Metro Liner map.svg|thumb|229x229px|Current [[Los Angeles Metro Rail]] map showing rail and rapid transit lines]] Downtown Los Angeles is the center of the region's growing rail transit system, with six commuter lines operated by [[Metrolink (Southern California)|Metrolink]], as well as five rapid-transit rail lines and local and regional bus service operated by [[Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] (Metro).
Major Metro stations in the district include [[Los Angeles Union Station]], [[Civic Center/Grand Park station]], [[Pershing Square station]], [[7th Street/Metro Center station]], [[Pico station]], and [[Little Tokyo/Arts District station]].
*The first leg of the modern [[Los Angeles County Metro Rail|Los Angeles Metro Rail system]], the [[Blue Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Blue Line]] light rail, debuted in 1990, followed by the [[Red Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Red Line]] heavy-rail subway line in 1993, the [[Green Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Green Line]] light rail in 1994, the [[Gold Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Gold Line]] light rail in 2003, and the [[Expo Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Expo Line]] light rail in 2012. *In late 2009, the [[Silver Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Silver Line]] bus rapid transit project opened, replacing two unconnected bus rapid transit lines with through service at street level through the downtown area. *In 2006, a portion of the Metro Red Line was rebranded by Metro as the [[Purple Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Purple Line]], a heavy-rail subway line which runs from [[Union Station (Los Angeles)|Union Station]] to [[Wilshire/Western station]] in [[Koreatown, Los Angeles, California|Koreatown]]. A [[Purple Line Extension|westward extension]] of the line to [[Westwood, Los Angeles, California|Westwood]] is currently under construction. *Metro operates an extensive bus network,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.net/riding_metro/maps/default.htm |title=Metro Maps |publisher=Metro.net |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref> including Metro Local, Metro Express commuter lines, and Metro Rapid<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.net/projects/rapid/ |title=Metro Rapid |publisher=Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref> buses with signal priority and limited stops. *[[Los Angeles Department of Transportation]] operates seven local [[LADOT DASH|DASH]] shuttle lines downtown on weekdays: Lines A, B, C, D, E and F.<ref name=dashsched>[http://ladottransit.com/dash/routes/downtown/downtown.html DASH Schedule], LADOT.</ref> Weekend service is operated on lines DD (Downtown Discovery), E and F.<ref name=dashweekendsched>[http://ladottransit.com/dash/routes/downtown_wkend/downtown_we.html DASH Weekend Schedule] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090615215316/http://ladottransit.com/dash/routes/downtown_wkend/downtown_we.html |date=June 15, 2009 }}, LADOT.</ref>
===Amtrak=== [[File:Union-Station-LA-Waiting-Ro.jpg|thumb|220px|[[Los Angeles Union Station]] main passenger concourse]]
Amtrak operates intercity passenger train service on five routes through [[Los Angeles Union Station]]: the [[Coast Starlight]], [[Pacific Surfliner]], [[Southwest Chief]], [[Sunset Limited]], and [[Texas Eagle]].
===Greyhound=== [[Greyhound Lines]] operates a major bus terminal in Downtown Los Angeles at the intersection of Seventh and Alameda streets.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greyhound.com/home/TicketCenter/en/locations.asp?state=ca |title=Locations: California |publisher=Greyhound.com |date= |accessdate=2009-06-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090707085226/http://www.greyhound.com/home/TicketCenter/en/locations.asp?state=ca |archivedate=2009-07-07 |df= }}</ref>
===Service to Los Angeles International Airport=== [[Los Angeles World Airports]] operates a direct shuttle every 30–60 minutes between [[Los Angeles Union Station|Union Station]] and [[Los Angeles International Airport]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawa.org/welcome_lax.aspx?id=4696|title=LAX FlyAway|accessdate=May 24, 2013|publisher=Los Angeles World Airports}}</ref>
===Transit expansion=== [[File:LACMTA-GoldLine.jpg|thumb|220px|[[Gold Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Gold Line light rail at Union Station]]]]
*The [[Expo Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Expo Line]] was built in two phases and completed in 2016. The first phase of the project connected [[7th St/Metro Center (LACMTA station)|7th Street/Metro Center Station]] downtown with Culver City via the former [[Pacific Electric Railway]] [[Santa Monica Air Line]] right-of-way. The second phase extended the line to [[Santa Monica]].<ref>[http://buildexpo.org/phase2_target_schedule.php ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524191730/http://buildexpo.org/phase2_target_schedule.php |date=May 24, 2009 }}</ref> The Expo Line shares tracks with the [[Blue Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Blue Line]] north of Washington Boulevard, and shares both the [[Pico (LACMTA station)|Pico Station]] and [[7th St/Metro Center (LACMTA station)|7th Street/Metro Center Station]] with the Blue Line. *[[Los Angeles Union Station]] is set to be a major stop on the under-construction [[California High-Speed Rail]] system, though it will not be a part of the project's Initial Operating Segment.<ref>"[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2009/06/though-california-is-in-the-throes-of-a-budget-crisis-vice-president-joe-biden-said-today-that-the-states-high-speed-rail.html Joe Biden says California high-speed rail looking good for federal money]", ''Los Angeles Times''.</ref> The project would connect Northern and Southern California via the [[San Joaquin Valley]], with service averaging {{convert|220|mph|km/h|sp=us}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cahighspeedrail.ca.gov/faqs/why.htm |title=Why High-Speed Trains? |publisher=Cahighspeedrail.ca.gov |date= |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/gulliver/2014/04/california-high-speed-rail |title=California high speed rail: Wobbling on its tracks |work=[[The Economist]] |date=2014-04-01 |accessdate=2015-09-25}}</ref> *Under construction as of September 2014, the Regional Connector Transit Corridor will connect the Blue, Expo, and Gold Lines between the Little Tokyo/Arts District (which will be renamed "1st Street/Central") and 7th Street/Metro Center stations. *Work is planned to bring [[streetcar]]-style trolley service to Downtown Los Angeles via [[Broadway (Los Angeles)|Broadway]], connecting the [[L.A. Live]] development with the Grand Avenue cultural corridor and [[Bunker Hill, Los Angeles|Bunker Hill]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bringingbackbroadway.com/updates/index.htm |title=Streetcar |publisher=Bringing Back Broadway |date= |accessdate=2009-06-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603003900/http://bringingbackbroadway.com/updates/index.htm |archivedate=2009-06-03 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bringingbackbroadway.com/timeline/index.htm |title=Progress |publisher=Bringing Back Broadway |date= |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref>
==Parks and open space== [[File:Lacathedral.jpg|thumb|[[Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels]] located adjacent to [[Los Angeles City Hall]]]] [[File:Pershing Square fountain, LA, CA, jjron 22.03.2012.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Pershing Square (Los Angeles)|Pershing Square]]]] [[File:Pershing square los angeles concert series.jpg|thumb|220px|Pershing Square during the park's Summer Concert Series]] Downtown Los Angeles is home to several public parks, plazas, gardens and other open space: *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090425235348/http://www.ci.la.ca.us/angelswalk/5.htm Biddy Mason Park] *[[Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels]] meditation garden and olive garden (park) *[[Grand Park]] *[[La Iglesia de Nuestra Señora Reina de los Angeles|La Placita Olvera]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081207023054/http://www.lacity.org/angelswalk/32%2633.htm Maguire Gardens] *[[Pershing Square (Los Angeles)|Pershing Square]] *[[Los Angeles City Hall]] South Lawn *[[Los Angeles Police Department]]'s Police Administration Building<ref>{{cite news|last=Green |first=Emily |url=http://www.latimes.com/features/home/la-hm-lapd23-2009may23,0,1601557.story |title=LAPD green: landscaping at the new police headquarters |work=Los Angeles Times |date=2009-05-23 |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref> South Lawn *[[Los Angeles State Historic Park]] *[[Los Angeles Union Station]] gardens *[[Walt Disney Concert Hall]] Community Park *The Water Court at [[One California Plaza|California Plaza]], an outdoor performance and dining space with water features, fountains, shaded seating areas and an amphitheater. *Japanese Garden and plaza at the Little Tokyo Cultural and Community Center Plaza *Japanese Garden at the [[Kyoto Grand Hotel and Gardens]] *Garden at [[Bank of America Center (Los Angeles)|Bank of America Plaza]]
Several future park proposals for the district make use of public-private partnerships between developers and the city of Los Angeles, including a public park at the proposed Nikkei Center development in [[Little Tokyo, Los Angeles|Little Tokyo]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20081010f2.html |title=Little Tokyo looks to get back its vibes with new development |work=The Japan Times Online |date=2008-10-10 |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref> a {{convert|1|acre|m2|adj=on}} park at the Medallion development in the Historic Core; and a [[pocket park]] at the [[Wilshire Grand Tower|Wilshire Grand Hotel]] replacement project, currently under construction.<ref>{{cite web|author=carllehmanpi.com |url=http://www.downtownnews.com/articles/2009/04/03/news/doc49d594ea82496067545550.txt |title=Los Angeles Downtown News and Information – LA Downtown News Online > Archives > News > Korean Air Plans $1 Billion Downtown Project |publisher=Downtownnews.com |date=2009-04-03 |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref>
Additionally, the city recently completed a new park located on the 400 block of South Spring Street in the [[Historic Core, Los Angeles|Historic Core]] neighborhood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://la.curbed.com/archives/2009/01/shiny_downtown_tower_is_out_new_park_in.php |title=Curbed LA: Shiny Downtown Tower Is Out, New Park Is In |publisher=La.curbed.com |date=2009-01-14 |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref>
==Skyline== {{Main|List of tallest buildings in Los Angeles}} [[File:Los Angeles Skyline.jpg|thumb|220px|The modern skyline of Los Angeles resulted from the termination of severe height restrictions in 1957]] Despite its relative decentralization and comparatively new high-rises (until 1958, the city did not permit any structures taller than the 27-story City Hall building <ref>{{cite web|url=http://studentreader.com/la-city-hall/#Building-City-Hall |title=LA City Hall - Student Reader |publisher=StudentReader.com |date=2012-10-24 |accessdate=2012-11-21}}</ref>), Los Angeles has one of the largest skylines in the [[United States]], and its development has continued in recent years.
The skyline has seen rapid growth due to improvements in seismic design standards, which has made certain building types highly earthquake-resistant. Many of the new skyscrapers contain a housing or hotel component.
Some current and upcoming examples of skyscraper construction include: *705 Ninth Street, a 35-story residential tower, was completed in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://la.curbed.com/archives/2009/11/it_turns_out_that_rumor.php|title=MerueloMaddux |publisher=MerueloMaddux |date= |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref> *717 Olympic, a 26-story residential tower, was completed in mid-2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://717olympic.com|title=UDR Apartments 717 Olympic|website=UDR.com}}</ref> *888 Olive, a 32-story apartment tower by Vancouver-based Omni Group, opened in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ladowntownnews.com/news/the-development-scene-the-latest-info-on-downtown-projects/article_b91d651e-c3d5-11e2-8963-001a4bcf887a.html|title=The Development Scene: The Latest Info on 88 Downtown Projects|first=Richard Guzmán, Jon Regardie and Ryan|last=Vaillancourt|publisher=}}</ref> *Concerto, a 28-story residential tower, was completed in early 2009. A second phase (Tower II) is currently under construction. *The [[Grand Avenue Project]], designed by architect [[Frank Gehry]], is a multi-phase project on four parcels and will include a 39-story hotel tower at the corner of First Street and Grand Avenue and a [[Grand Park|civic park]].<ref>[http://thegrandla.com The Grand] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415174039/http://thegrandla.com/ |date=April 15, 2009 }}. Thegrandla.com. Retrieved on 2013-07-29.</ref> The project has been delayed due to funding issues but is now back on track and progressing.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2009/02/grand-avenue-pr.html | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=L.A. Now | date=2009-02-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://urbanize.la/post/surprise-grand-avenue-project-files-construction-permits|title=Surprise: Grand Avenue Project Files for Construction Permits|date=11 August 2017|publisher=}}</ref> *[[L.A. Live]], a multi-phased dining, entertainment and hotel development that includes a [[Ritz-Carlton]] and [[JW Marriott]] Hotel hybrid as well as Ritz-Carlton-branded condominiums, was completed in February, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lalive.com/content.php?section=hotels&page=ritz_carlton_residences |title=L.A. Live |publisher=L.A. Live, which opened in July 2014, and plans to build a 20+ story [[Renaissance Hotels|Renaissance hotel]] to open in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.travelagewest.com/Travel/News/L-A--Live-to-Get-New-Renaissance-Hotel/#.Uhu7HNK-rfg|title=404 LC : TravelAge West|website=www.travelagewest.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/mar/07/business/la-fi-property-report-20130307 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Roger | last=Vincent | title=Marriott doubles down on high-rise hotels in L.A | date=2013-03-07}}</ref> *Metropolis, a mixed-use four tower project (60, 50, 38, and 19-stories) at Francisco and Ninth streets, is currently under construction.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-07-26/china-s-greenland-enters-u-s-in-1-billion-los-angeles-project.html | work=Bloomberg | title=China's Greenland Buys Stake in Los Angeles Project}}</ref> *''South'', a three-tower complex called Elleven, Luma, and Evo, spans the block from 11th Street and Grand Avenue to 12th Street and Grand Avenue, and was completed in phases ending in early 2009. *The [[Wilshire Grand Tower]] redevelopment, a 900-room hotel and office project is built in 2017 as the tallest tower west of the [[Mississippi River]], at {{convert|1,100|ft|m}}.<ref>{{cite news|author=|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2009/04/amid-slump-one-part-of-downtown-remains-hot.html |title=Amid slump, one part of downtown remains hot |work=Los Angeles Times |date= 2009-04-07|accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref> *[[Figueroa Centre]], a 975-foot residential and hotel tower proposed across from [[The Original Pantry]] restaurant on the [[Figueroa Corridor]].
