===Building height limits: 1904-1957=== [[File:LA Eastern Columbia Building.jpg|thumb|The [[Eastern Columbia Building]]: the Entrance to the [[Historic Core, Los Angeles|Historic Core]] and the "Jewel of Downtown"]] The first height limit ordinance in Los Angeles was enacted following the completion of the 13-story [[Continental Building]], located at the southeast corner of Fourth and Spring streets. The purpose of the height limit was to limit the density of the city. There was great hostility to skyscrapers in many cities in these years, mainly due to the congestion they could bring to the streets, and height limit ordinances were a common way of dealing with the problem. In 1911, the city passed an updated height limit ordinance, establishing a specific limit of {{convert|150|ft|m}}. Exceptions were granted for decorative towers such as those later built on the [[Eastern Columbia Building]] and United Artists Theatre, as well as the now-demolished [[Richfield Tower]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.4wilshire.com|title=The Latest On AXS|publisher=}}</ref>
The 1911 ordinance was repealed in 1957. The first private building to exceed the old limit was the 18-story United California Bank Building, located at the southeast corner of Sixth and Spring streets.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}}
===Flat Roof Ordinance=== The pattern of buildings in Los Angeles to feature these "flat roofs" was the result of a 1974 fire ordinance which required all tall buildings in the city to include rooftop [[helipad]]s in response to the devastating 1974 [[Joelma Fire]] in [[Sao Paulo, Brazil]], in which helicopters were used to affect rescues from the flat rooftop of the building.<ref>Rosenberg, Jeremy (January 16, 2012) [http://www.kcet.org/socal/departures/columns/laws-that-shaped-la/laws-that-shaped-la-why-is-the-la-skyline-so-bland.html "Laws That Shaped L.A.: Why is the Los Angeles Skyline So Bland?"] [[KCET]]</ref> The [[Wilshire Grand Center]] was the first building granted an exception by the [[Los Angeles City Fire Department]] in 2014. However, as the building was under construction, [[Los Angeles City Council|L.A. City Council]] removed the flat roof ordinance as of 2015.<ref>Glick Kudler, Adrian (February 7, 2013) [http://la.curbed.com/archives/2013/02/new_wilshire_grand_will_be_the_west_coasts_tallest_tower.php "New Wilshire Grand Will Be the West Coast's Tallest Tower"] [[Curbed|CURBED Los Angeles]]</ref>
==Government and infrastructure== [[File:Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, Los Angeles.JPG|thumb|[[Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco]], Los Angeles Branch. This building is now loft apartments.]] The [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]] operates the Central Health Center in Downtown Los Angeles.<ref>"[http://publichealth.lacounty.gov/phn/docs/HealthCenter/central.pdf Central Health Center]", [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]. Retrieved on March 18, 2010.</ref>
The Southern California Liaison of the [[California Department of Education]] has its office in the [[Ronald Reagan]] State Building in Downtown Los Angeles.<ref>"[http://www.cde.ca.gov/re/di/cd/liaison.asp Southern California Liaison]", [[California Department of Education]]. Retrieved on December 23, 2009.</ref>
The [[Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, Los Angeles Branch]] is located in Downtown Los Angeles.<ref>"[http://www.frbsf.org/federalreserve/branches/index.html FRBSF Branches]", [[Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco]]. Retrieved on March 30, 2010.</ref>
==Economy== DTLA is a node in the tech economy that extends beyond [[Silicon Beach]]. A venture capital firm counted 78 tech-oriented firms in DTLA in 2015. This included mobile apps, hardware, digital media and clean-tech companies plus co-working spaces, start-up incubators, and other related businesses.<ref name=tech/>
The [[Arts District, Los Angeles|Arts District]] has become a popular spot for companies seeking out something different than typical modern offices. The central location is accessible from various parts of the Los Angeles Basin. The cultural life has also made the area attractive to young tech employees.<ref name=tech>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-dtla-tech-20150308-story.html#page=1|title=Tech scene takes hold in revitalized downtown L.A.|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=March 7, 2015|first= Andrea |last= Chang}}</ref>
[[Anschutz Entertainment Group]] has its corporate headquarters in Downtown Los Angeles.<ref>[http://www.aegworldwide.com/home.html Anschutz Entertainment Group] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060707101145/http://www.aegworldwide.com/home.html |date=July 7, 2006 }}. Retrieved on November 9, 2009.</ref>
[[BYD Company]], a Chinese technology firm, has its North American headquarters in Downtown Los Angeles.<ref>"[http://bydit.com/doce/contact/ContactUs/index.html Contact Us] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222193031/http://bydit.com/doce/contact/ContactUs/index.html |date=February 22, 2015 }}." BYD Company. Retrieved on June 17, 2015. "BYD North America Headquarters Add.:1800 S. Figueroa Street, Los Angeles, CA90015, USA"</ref>
[[Cathay Bank]] has its headquarters in the [[Chinatown, Los Angeles|Los Angeles Chinatown]].<ref>"[https://www.cathaybank.com/CathayBank/media/Cathay-General/PDF/2014-Annual-Report_w-10K_Revised.pdf 2014 Annual Report 2014]" ([https://www.webcitation.org/6gJyLiWta?url=https://www.cathaybank.com/CathayBank/media/Cathay-General/PDF/2014-Annual-Report_w-10K_Revised.pdf Archive]). Cathay Bank. Retrieved on March 27, 2016. p. 18. "Corporate Headquarter 777 N. Broadway Los Angeles, CA 90012"</ref>
==Education== [[File:ColburnSchoolFront.jpg|thumb|220px|Colburn School on Grand Boulevard]] [[File:Central LA High School for the Visual and Performing Arts.jpg|thumb|220px|Ramon C. Cortines High School for the Visual and Performing Arts]]
Downtown residents aged 25 and older holding a four-year degree amounted to 17.9% of the population in 2000, about average in the city and the county, but there was a high percentage of residents with less than a high school diploma.<ref name=MappingLADowntown/>
These are the elementary or secondary schools within the neighborhood's boundaries:<ref name=MappingLASchoolsDowntown>[http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/neighborhood/downtown/schools] "Downtown Schools," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''</ref> * [[Ramon C. Cortines School Of Visual And Performing Arts|Ramon C. Cortines School of Visual and Performing Arts]], [[LAUSD]] high school, 450 N. Grand Ave. * [[Downtown Magnets High School|Downtown Business High School]], LAUSD alternative, 1081 W. Temple St. * [[California Academy for LS|California Academy for Liberal Studies Early College High School]], LAUSD charter, 700 Wilshire Blvd. * Alliance Dr. Olga Mohan High School, LAUSD charter, 644 W. 17th St. * Abram Friedman Occupational School, LAUSD adult education, 1646 S. Olive St. * Metropolitan Continuation School, LAUSD, 727 S. Wilson St. * Para Los Ninos Middle School, LAUSD charter, 1617 E. Seventh St. * Jardin de la Infancia, LAUSD charter elementary, 307 E. Seventh St. * [[Saint Malachy]] Catholic Elementary School, private, 1200 E. 81st St. * Tri-C Community Day School, LAUSD, 716 E. 14th St. * City of Angels School, LAUSD alternative school, 1449 S. San Pedro St. (formerly Central High School)<ref name=ThomasGuideDowntownLA/> * San Pedro Street Elementary School, LAUSD, 1635 S. San Pedro St. * [[Saint Turibius]] Elementary School, private, 1524 Essex St. * [[American University Preparatory School]], private, 345 S. Figueroa St.
The [[Fashion Institute of Design & Merchandising]] is at 800 S. Hope St.,<ref name=ThomasGuideDowntownLA/><ref>Mapping L.A.,''Los Angeles Times''</ref> and the [[Colburn School]] for music and the performing arts is at 200 S. Grand Ave.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colburnschool.edu/page.cfm?p%3D2260 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130501172212/http://www.colburnschool.edu/page.cfm?p=2260 |archivedate=2013-05-01 |df= }} Colburn School website</ref>
==Emergency services== ===Hospitals=== Dignity Health-California Hospital Medical Center is located in the South Park district of Downtown LA at 1401 S. Grand Ave. The 318-bed community hospital has been providing high-quality care to residents of the district and its neighboring communities for over 126 years. Dignity Health-California Hospital Medical Center is known for its wide range of medical services, from women's health and maternal child to orthopedics and cardiology. The hospital also operates the only Level II Trauma Center in Downtown Los Angeles, and its emergency room treats over 70,000 patients each year. The hospital's neighbors include [[Staples Center]], [[L.A. Live]], [[Fashion Institute of Design & Merchandising]] and the [[Fashion District (Los Angeles)|Fashion District]].
===Fire services=== [[File:City hall triforium.jpg|thumb|220px|The [[Triforium (Los Angeles)|Triforium]] sculpture with [[Los Angeles City Hall]] in the background]] The [[Los Angeles Fire Department]] operates the following fire stations in Downtown Los Angeles: *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070630061811/http://lafd.org/fs3.htm Station 3] (Civic Center/Bunker Hill) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090416084854/http://www.lafd.org/fs4.htm Station 4] (Little Tokyo/Chinatown/Union Station/Olvera Street) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070630061805/http://lafd.org/fs9.htm Station 9] (Central City/Skid Row) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081121032328/http://www.lafd.org/fs10.htm Station 10] (Convention Center area)
===Police services=== The [[Los Angeles Police Department]] operates the [http://lapdonline.org/central_community_police_station Central Area Community Police Station] in Downtown Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lapdonline.org/central_community_police_station |title=Central Community Police Station – official website of THE LOS ANGELES POLICE DEPARTMENT |publisher=Lapdonline.org |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref>

Its global headquarters are in [[Causeway, County Kerry|Causeway]], [[County Kerry]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]].{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/finance/2012/1026/1224325733001.html|title=Kerry dairy business scoops top prize|accessdate=2 January 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615053704/http://www.irishtimes.com/business/sectors/agribusiness-and-food/kerry-dairy-business-scoops-top-prize-1.557809|archivedate=15 June 2013|first=Pamela |last=Newenham|date=26 October 2012|work=[[The Irish Times]]}} In 2012 Harty was presented with the title of International and overall [[Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award|Ernst and Young Entrepreneur of the Year]] by President of Ireland [[Michael D. Higgins]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ucd.ie/innovation/newsevents/newsarchive/2012/october/ucdgraduateisnamedtheernstyoung2012entrepreneuroftheyear/name,140933,en.html |title=UCD Graduate is Named the Ernst & Young 2012 Entrepreneur of the Year |publisher=[[University College Dublin]] |date=26 October 2012|accessdate=18 August 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ey.com/IE/en/Newsroom/News-releases/Press-release-2012---Agri-Pioneer-named-as-Ernst---Young-Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year-for-2012 |title=Agri’ Pioneer named as EY Entrepreneur Of The Year for 2012|website=Ey.com |date=26 October 2012 |accessdate=18 August 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2012/1026/edmond-harty-wins-ernst-young-entrepreneur-prize-business.html|title=Edmond Harty named as Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the year|accessdate=2 January 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115133913/http://www.rte.ie/news/2012/1026/edmond-harty-wins-ernst-young-entrepreneur-prize-business.html|archivedate=15 January 2013|date=26 October 2012|website=Rte.ie}} Harty is a mechanical engineer by profession with a degree from [[University of Limerick]]. He joined Dairymaster in 1998, while studying for a PhD in [[University College Dublin]] where he focused on milking performance.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/sectors/agribusiness-and-food/dairy-entrepreneur-who-became-cream-of-the-crop-1.549425|title=Dairy entrepreneur who became cream of the crop|accessdate=2 January 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203211543/http://www.irishtimes.com/business/sectors/agribusiness-and-food/dairy-entrepreneur-who-became-cream-of-the-crop-1.549425|archivedate=3 February 2014|date=9 November 2012|first=Alison |last=Healy|work=The Irish Times}} He is a member of the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO) and the International Dairy Federation (IDF), the foremost scientific groups in milking globally.{{cite web|url=http://www.ahirl.ie/edhartybio.php |title=Edmund Harty |website=Ahirl.ie |accessdate=18 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201195441/http://www.ahirl.ie/edhartybio.php |archivedate=1 February 2014 |df= }} Harty has pioneered a number of new products and has over 40 patents filed to date as a result of work on product development with devices ranging from vacuum regulators and electronic milk metering to state of the art animal feeding systems.{{cite web|url=http://www.animalhealthireland.ie/page.php?id=41 |title=CellCheck Programme - Technical Working Group |publisher=Animalhealthireland.ie |date= |accessdate=18 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224024823/http://www.animalhealthireland.ie/page.php?id=41 |archivedate=24 February 2015 |df= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.dairymaster.com/ Dairymaster official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Harty, Edmond}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Irish businesspeople]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Limerick]] [[Category:Alumni of University College Dublin]] [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]]

{{Multiple issues|{{one source|date=July 2018}}{{technical|date=July 2018}}}}
The '''equivalence number method''' is a cost calculation method for co-production in [[cost accounting|cost and activity accounting]]. The resulting costs of the input factors are allocated to the individual products according to a [[weighting]] key, the so-called equivalence numbers.
== Description ==
As with the other cost allocation methods, the conservation of the cost sum applies, that is:
:<math>\text{sum of cost input} = \text{sum of cost output}</math>
The cost of the main product, usually for the product with the highest physical or economical output, receives for example the equivalence number 1. On the basis of selected indicators (average market prices, physical properties, etc.) other equivalence numbers are formed, using suitable ratios between the different co-products. Multiplying the equivalence numbers by the production or sales figures results in the allocation keys for a specific product type. From this the cost of a co-product can be calculated, both for main and by-products.
== Mathematical background ==
From an one-dimensional input I, a two-dimensional output is assumed with ''O<sub>1</sub> = f<sub>1</sub>(I) * I'' and ''O<sub>2</sub> = f<sub>2</sub>(I) * I''.
Note: One interpretation for ''f'' is a conversion efficiency from the input to the respective output. More than 2 co-products are also conceivable.
The costs ''k<sub>1</sub>'', ''k<sub>2</sub>'' are the variable costs of the two outputs which need to be determined. ''k<sub>I</sub>'' represents the known variable costs of the input. ''K<sup>var</sup>'' denotes the respective sum of the variable costs. ''a<sub>1</sub>'' and ''a<sub>2</sub>'' are the allocation factors for the respective output, i.e. they describe the proportion of the input that is assigned to a co-product.
The weighting keys are ''f<sub>1</sub>'' and ''f<sub>2</sub>'':
:<math>K_1^{var} = a_1 \cdot K_I^{var} = \frac{f_1}{f_1 + f_2} \cdot k_I \cdot I \quad \text{respectively} \quad K_2^{var} = a_2 \cdot K_I^{var} = \frac{f_2}{f_1 + f_2} \cdot k_I \cdot I</math>
This results in specific variable costs ''k<sub>1</sub>'' and ''k<sub>2</sub>'':
:<math>k_1 = \frac{K^{var}_1}{O_1} = \frac{K^{var}_1}{f_1 \cdot I} \quad \text{respectively} \quad k_2 = \frac{K^{var}_2}{O_2} = \frac{K^{var}_2}{f_2 \cdot I}</math>
According to the introducing relation of the cost allocation, the following applies:
:<math> k_I \cdot I = k_1 \cdot O_1 + k_2 \cdot O_2 \quad \text{or} \quad K_I^{var} = K_1^{var} + K_2^{var}</math>
== Application examples ==
An [[airline]] can determine the cost of the transportation service by dividing air [[freight]] and [[passengers]] by [[weight]]. The average passenger weight of booked seats is to be compared to the weight of the loaded air cargo containers.
* a<sub>pass</sub> = m<sub>pass</sub> / (m<sub>pass</sub> + m<sub>freight</sub>) * a<sub>freight</sub> = m<sub>freight</sub> / (m<sub>pass</sub> + m<sub>freight</sub>)
In a [[refinery]], one can assume the input as [[crude oil]] and as output [[gasoline]], [[Diesel fuel|diesel]] and [[heavy fuel oil]] as well as (flare) losses. The equivalence number method can use the [[energy]] content of the products as an allocation key. E is the product of energy density and production quantity.
* a<sub>gas</sub> = E<sub>gas</sub> / (E<sub>gas</sub> + E<sub>diesel</sub> + E<sub>HFO</sub>) * a<sub>diesel</sub> = E<sub>diesel</sub> / (E<sub>gas</sub> + E<sub>diesel</sub> + E<sub>HFO</sub>) * a<sub>HFO</sub> = E<sub>HFO</sub> / (E<sub>gas</sub> + E<sub>diesel</sub> + E<sub>HFO</sub>)
In the [[cogeneration]] plants, the [[Carnot method]] allocates the fuel to the products useful heat and electrical work as the key to the [[exergy]] content of the beneficial energies.
* a<sub>el</sub>= η<sub>el</sub> / (η<sub>el</sub> + η<sub>c</sub> × η<sub>th</sub>) * a<sub>th</sub>= (η<sub>c</sub> x η<sub>th</sub>) / (η<sub>el</sub> + η<sub>c</sub> × η<sub>th</sub>)
In the alternative generation method, the key is thermal and weighted electrical efficiency, where the weighting factor is the ratio of thermal to electrical reference efficiencies (γ = η<sub>th,ref</sub>/η<sub>el,ref</sub>).
* a<sub>el</sub>= (γ η<sub>el</sub>) / (γ η<sub>el</sub> + η<sub>th</sub>) * a<sub>th</sub>= η<sub>th</sub> / (γ η<sub>el</sub> + η<sub>th</sub>)
== Criticism ==
Criticism of the equivalence number method is justified by the fact that completely arbitrary and random keys can be chosen. For example, in the case of allocating the potable water bill in a house with only one common meter, the water consumption could be divided according to the number of occupants per apartment or the apartment's net dwelling area in m².
== Further reading == * Günter Wöhe: Einführung in die allgemeine Betriebswirtschaftslehre (DE: Introduction in general business economics). 18th edition. Vahlen, München 1993, {{ISBN|3-8006-1728-5}}.
== See also == * [[Cross-multiplication]] (or rule of proportion) * [[Cost allocation]]

'''Felice Bisleri''' (30 November, 1851- 17 September, 1921) was an Italian businessman, inventor and chemist. He was born<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sanpellegrinoterme.gov.it/files/giornalespt/bra/210925G.pdf|title=Un lutto dell'industria termominerale italiana - La morte di Felice Bisleri. Giornale di San Pellegrino|last=|first=|date=1921|website=|publisher=Società Volonté & C.|access-date=}}</ref> in [[Verolanuova]] near [[Brescia]] and established the Felice Bisleri & Co. chemical laboratory in [[Milan]], developing the successful "Ferro-China Bisleri", an [[amaro (drink)]] made as an alcohol infusion of [[cinchona]] bark, [[herb]]s, and [[iron]] salts. The company also made the wellselling "Nocera Umbra" [[mineral water]] named after [[Nocera Umbra]] (1894), as well as the "Esanofele", a chemical based on [[quinine]], [[iron]] and [[arsenic]] to combat [[malaria]] (1899).<ref>[http://bms.beniculturali.it/ritratti/ritratti.php?chiave=ritr0100 Medica in posa] and [http://www.ilserrasanta.it/eco/20010923/11ricordo.html Ricordo di Felice Bislieri]</ref>
Bisleri died in [[San Pellegrino]]. The ''Via Felice Bisleri'' in Milano is named after him. The [[Bisleri]] mineral water brand still exists, having been sold to [[India]]'s Parle in the 1969.
==Awards== *[[Silver Medal of Military Valor]] for his fighting at the [[Battle of Bezzecca]] (21 July, 1866)

[[Image:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-14750-0003, Bautzen, Auszubildende bei einer Montage.jpg|thumb|right|[[Tractor]] being assembled stands still, while [[workers]] and [[tools]] move to complete required operations]]
'''Fixed position assembly''' refers to an assembly system or situation in which the product does not move while being assembled, this configuration is usually contrasted in [[operations management]] and [[industrial engineering]] with [[assembly lines]]. Dimensioning this system is very simple: considering CP as [[productive capacity]] and T as average assembly time, then N, number of working stations, is given by N=CP*T.
[[Image:Assembly of Ottoman airplane.jpg|thumb|right|Ottoman [[airplane]] being assembled during WWI. Even thought airplane assembly is often cited as an example of fixed position system, today many airplanes go through assembly lines.]] [[Image:Water turbine construction.png|thumb|right|Water [[turbine]] being assembled]]
==Advantages==
*high system flexibility: both in introducing new products and attaining product customization *high variability in operations naturally lends itself to introducing [[job enlargement]] (to the benefit of the worker) *low investment: only "capital" needed are generic worker tools.
==Disadvantages==
*High work in progress *Significant space occupancy *Higher labor costs: workers need to know how to perform all operations of the technological cycle and therefore skilled labor needs to be employed (this is in sharp contrast to the [[assembly line]] in which a worker needs almost no training thanks to [[division of labour]] being carried to its extreme.
==See also==
*[[Operations management#Production systems|Production systems]]
==Further reading== *A. Portioli, A. Pozzetti, Progettazione dei sistemi produttivi, Hoepli 2003
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=avFLFuuY30s#! Boeing being assembled]

The '''global march against child labor''' came about in 1998, following the significant response concerning the desire to end [[child labor]]. It was a [[grassroot]] movement that motivated many individuals and organizations to come together and fight against child labor and not an annual march.
The main goals of this movement was to: * "Protect and promote the rights of all children, especially the [[right to education|rights to receive free, meaningful education]]"<ref name=about>http://www.globalmarch.org/aboutus/index.php</ref> * "To be free from [[economic exploitation]] and from performing any work that is likely to be damaging to a child's physical, mental, spiritual, moral or social development". The march was very successful and it achieved its purpose by allowing changes to occur with the policies of [[child labour]] with the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO)<ref name=about/>
==Overview== This march began on January 17, 1998 under the leadership of [[Kailash Satyarthi]] <ref>[http://www.crin.org/organisations/viewOrg.asp?ID=1813 CRIN - Child Rights Information Network - Organisations - Global March Against Child Labour<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> This event was a global [[conjuncture]] that brought [[non-governmental organizations]] (NGOs), [[trade unions]], teachers, children and individuals together to fight against [[child labour]]. People from all over the world came together. There were people who marched only within their region and there were others who continued to Geneva, Switzerland. They were called the core marchers.
The marchers united and advanced through Africa, Asia, Europe, Latin America and the U.S. Their final destination was Geneva, Switzerland where the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) meeting was taking place. At this conference, the issues of [[child labour]] and implementing new policies in order to prevent it on the global level were discussed. This march was significant at the ILO convention against the worst forms of child labor otherwise known as [[Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention, 1999|Convention no. 182]], because: # The marchers' opinions were heavily considered while writing out the draft. # Also, it became the fastest ratified convention in the history of ILO with 150 countries adopting this draft.
This march was important to children in the work field since the underlying cause was to banish economic exploitation, not only in labor fields, but also through [[human trafficking]] where children are usually sold off for commercial services.
For those students that were not able to physically participate in the march, they were able to participate in an Online March sponsored by the [[Quincy Public Schools|Massachusetts-based Kids Campaign to “Build a School for Iqbal”]]. Over 3,000 classrooms with students published messages on the Global March web page.<ref name=onlinemarch>[http://www.nclnet.org/march.htm]</ref>
Several goals were created and collectively agreed upon by the delegates of the supporting organizations for the Global March:<ref name="onlinemarch"/>
* Increase attention and consciousness in regards to [[child labor]] * Encourage the [[ratification]] and implementation of surviving [[child labor]] and education conventions and laws by states * Assemble the most achievable national and international resources to sustain [[education]] for all children * Marshal public opinion and engagement against the extensive prejudices contributing to [[child labor]] * Commanding the urgent eradication of the majority of oppressive forms of child labor * Endorse constructive actions by consumers and employees * Guarantee adequate treatments and reincorporation of child laborers
==Organizations that are Involved== Currently, there are many organizations that supported the cause of the global march:<ref name=aboutthegm>http://www.globalmarch.org/aboutus.aboutthegm.php</ref> * [[Education International]] * [[Oxfam International]] * [[Action Aid]] * [[World Vision]] * [[Social Alert]] * [[World Confederation of Teachers]] * [[Save the Children Fund]] (UK) * [[Public Services International]] (PSI) * [[Free The Children]] * [[Mani Tese]]
==International Steering Committee== An International Steering Committee (membership is pulled from almost every continent) for the Global March against child labor was formed and consisted of:
* African Network for the Prevention and Protection Against Child Abuse and Neglect in [[Kenya]] * [[Anti-Slavery International]] in the [[United Kingdom]] * [[Education International]] in [[Belgium]] * FundaHao ABRINQ in [[Brazil]] * [[International Labor Rights Forum|International Labor Rights Fund]] in [[United States|United States of America]] * Network against Child Labour in [[South Africa]] * Novib in the [[Netherlands]] * Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Center for Human Rights in the United States of America * [[Bachpan Bachao Andolan|South Asian Coalition on Child Servitude]] in [[India]] * Terre des Hommes-Suisse in [[Switzerland]]
==Benefits== This march was important to children because it discourages them to experience [[economic]] exploitation in the labor field such as [[human trafficking]]. The policies that were introduced through this march emphasized highly on [[education]]. When children are educated it helps the economy since they are more likely to get out of their [[poverty]] stricken situation. By limiting education, it is limiting the prosperity
==Origins of this March== The march had 140 different countries that participated the act with thousands of partners.<ref>http://www.campaignforeducation.org/resources/Nov2001/OutofShadows.doc</ref> It consisted of events, rallies, foot marches and bus caravans.<ref>http://www.nclnet.org/marchinf.htm</ref> The first country that began the march was in Manila, Philippines on January 17, 1998. The marches took place in Asia, Africa, Latin America and the United States. Out of all of those people who participated in the march, only the select few known as the core marchers moved on to Geneva, Switzerland where the ILO were meeting for a possible revision of a new international convention on the most intolerable forms of child labor (Convention no. 182).<ref name=laborrights>http://laborrights.org/press/march050198.htm</ref>
The United States led their own nationwide march. It began in Los Angeles, California on May 2, 1998. The marchers went through all the major cities such as: Dallas, Little Rock, St Louis, Detroit and New York. The last city they visited was Washington, D.C. on May 26, 1998. From there, the core marchers went to Geneva, Switzerland. "The U.S. march has two main goals: to focus attention on domestic child labor problems, particularly those related to sweatshops and migrant agricultural work, and to encourage consumers to demand, retailers to sell and manufacturers to produce child-labor-free goods".<ref name=laborrights/>
Within their nationwide march many organizations got actively involved. These U.S. organizations co-sponsored the Global March against Child Labor.<ref name=usorganizations>http://www.nclnet.org/march.htm</ref>
* [[AFL-CIO]] * [[American Federation of Teachers]] * Association of Farmworker Opportunity Programs * Childreach/US Member of PLAN * International Child Labor Coalition * Church of the Brethren General Board/Office of Brethren Witness * Community Action on Latin America * [[Women of Truckee Making History|Dr. Homa Darabi Foundation]] * Free the Children/U.S.A. * General Federation of Women's Clubs * Global Kids Inc. * International Labour Organization Washington/Branch Office * [[International Labor Rights Forum|International Labor Rights Fund]] * The Kids Campaign To "Build A School for Iqbal"/[[Quincy Public Schools|Broad Meadows Middle School]] * Kids Meeting Kids Can Make a Difference * [[National Consumers League]] * [[Ethical Culture|Political and Social Action Committee/Washington Ethical Society]] * Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Center for Human Rights * [[General Board of Church and Society|United Methodist Church General Board of Church and Society]] * United Methodist Church: Women's Division General Board of Global Ministries * Washington Ethical Action Office/American Ethical Union * [[Women's Environment & Development Organization]] * [[Advocates for Youth|Youth Advocate Program International]]
==Rise to Prominence== The march was a success since the revision of a new international convention on the most intolerable forms of child labor [[Convention No 182]] was changed the following year. Through this march, Convention no. 182 became the fastest ratified law.<ref>[http://www.globalmarch.org/aboutus/achievements.php Global March Against Child Labour - From Exploitation to Education<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> This decree became the guideline for governments internationally when creating labor laws. Currently, over 150 countries have adopted Convention no. 182 in their own nation.
Kailash Satyarthi is largely responsible for taking the initiative of organizing this march. He had a vision of eliminating child labor everywhere and allowing education to become highly accessible for children. Kailash Satyarthi was the moving force in shifting our attention to child labor as a social issue. Through his tireless efforts, he has “brought political and judiciary machinery into action, and sensitized media in favor of the most oppressed children”.<ref>http://www.kailashsatyarthi.net/biography/</ref> His work did not stop after this march instead, he moved on to other projects such as Global Campaign for Education to promote universal education.
==Evolution== This march initiated other events to come together to fight against child labor. The march spread the awareness of eliminating child labor in our society and worldwide. Here are some examples of events that branched off from this march: * South Asian March against Child Trafficking * UN announced the Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking * Global Campaign for Education * The World Cup Campaign 2002 * Fair Chocolate for the World * Northern Advocacy Office in Washington D.C.
==The First Children’s World Congress on Child Labour== The First Children’s World Congress on Child Labour (CWWCL) was held in May 2004 in Florence, [[Italy]]. The event was organized by the Global March against Child Labor and other [[grassroots]] organizations.
Children were invited to the event through selection where at the Congress they were able to interact and communicate their views on the most pertinent concerns connected to their childhood and adolescence. They disclosed their experiences, dreams and ambitions as well as partake in various activities that lead to the formation of [[Goal|Action Plans]]. The selections for the Congress were made through democratic consultation processes (nominated by other children) at the national and local levels. Most of the representatives were former [[Child Labour|child laborers]] that got assistance from education and [[Vocational Education|vocational training]] in local [[Civic Society|civic organizations]] or treatment centers; however some were still working so they could pay for their education and some were chosen to represent associations such as [[trade union|Trade Unions]] and Child Rights Organizations.
This Congress was significant because it was the first Congress where children were the focus and were the chief spokespersons, decision makers and recipients. Approximately 200 children ages 11 to 17 were in attendance. The children that took part in the Congress came from diverse backgrounds and cultures and represented various regions, countries and organizations
This conference was crucial in understanding child labor and work [[Exploitation of labour|exploitation]]<ref name=childlabourcongress>Biggeri, Mario, et al. "Children Conceptualizing their Capabilities: Results of a Survey Conducted during the First Children's World Congress on Child Labour*." Journal of Human Development 7.1 (2006): 59-83. Academic Search Premier. EBSCO. Web. 9 Nov. 2009.</ref>
==Facts and Statistics== * 1997: ILO estimated between 100 million and 200 million child laborers in the world<ref name="onlinemarch"/> * 2004: ILO estimated that there were 218 million child laborers worldwide, with 7 of 10 working in agriculture * In order to globally abolish child labor, ILO approximates an expense of $38 billion per year for 20 years. * In 2001, Indian government confessed to having 12.7 million child laborers * In Brazil in order to convince parents to send their children to school instead of work, the government pays families $4.50 per child a month. Currently, there are more than 1 million participants<ref name=newstatistics>[Stokes, Bruce "When Childhood Is Denied." National Journal (2008): 17. Academic Search Premier. EBSCO. Web. 9 Nov. 2009.]</ref> *In Guatemala, female child laborers typically work 21 hours a week on domestic responsibilities coupled with a 40-hour working week beyond this.<ref name=guatemala>["Global March Against Child Labour." Women's International Network News 23.4 (1997): 75. Academic Search Premier. EBSCO. Web. 9 Nov. 2009.]</ref>
==Events== At a match against [[Germany]] on April 17, 2002, the [[Argentine national football team|Argentina National Team]] demonstrated their unity on abolishing child labor. They lifted a banner that read, “The only work for children should be to go to school"<ref name=events>http://www.cridoc.net/newsletter/july_2004/red_card.php</ref>
On January 17, 2004, the Global March against Child Labor celebrated its 6th anniversary in [[Quezon City]]. The celebration was held at the Occupational Safety and Health Center where more than 5,000 children and their parents marched from [[Quezon Memorial Circle]] to honor the movement. The ILO, government organizations, churches and other organizations were present at the celebration.
Political candidates were invited in hopes of convincing them to incorporate child labor issue in their platforms. The candidates were introduced to the issue of [[child labor]] and conversed with the children.
After the traditional signing of the [[Anti-Trafficking in Persons Act of 2003|RA 9231]] all participants joined hands in giving appreciation to the strides made and rewards received because of the successes achieved by the Global March movement. Invited artists and chosen groups of child laborers showcased any talents and artistic skills they possessed in activities such as dancing, singing and playing musical instruments"<ref name=oneevent>http://www.dole.gov.ph/news/details.asp?id=N000000244</ref> .
==Recent events== The next country to encounter the march is Zimbabwe. The march will take place on December 1–31, 2007. It will start at Harare and end in Plumtree. The goal is to combat child labor and to spread education to the children of that country. Media outlets will be used to promote this event through television, newspaper and radio. One of the major organizations that are contributing to this march is the New Hope Foundation.
==References== http://www.NL-Aid.org {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox person | image = | name = Grażyna Kulczyk | caption = Grażyna Kulczyk | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1950|11|5|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Poznań]], Poland | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Polish | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = [[Adam Mickiewicz University]] | occupation = investor, art collector | known for = | salary = | networth = | spouse = [[Jan Kulczyk]] | parents = | children = [[Dominika Kulczyk]],
[[Sebastian Kulczyk]] | website = }} '''Grażyna Kulczyk''' (1950–present) is a Polish investor, art collector and philanthropist. Her areas of interest and art commissions combine a number of themes. She is a champion of contemporary art and supporter of avant-garde choreography while also supporting development of new technology and start-ups working to change the world. She is particularly engaged in supporting entrepreneurship among women as well as the equal presence of women in STEM. As a member of the Russia and Eastern Europe Acquisitions Committee, Ms. Kulczyk supports London’s Tate Modern. She joined the board of the Modern Women’s Fund Committee of the Museum of Modern Art, New York in 2015, and has been a board member of Museum of Modern Art in Warsaw for almost 10 years. Ms. Kulczyk has been recognised as one of the 200 Top Collectors in the world by Art News magazine.{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200/grazyna-kulczyk/|title=Grażyna Kulczyk -|website=ARTnews|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.handelszeitung.ch/invest/die-zehn-wichtigsten-player-im-kunst-business|title=Die zehn wichtigsten Player im Kunst-Business - Handelszeitung|work=Handelszeitung|access-date=2018-09-17|language=de-DE}} Kulczyk is the former wife of [[Jan Kulczyk]] with whom she had two children, [[Dominika Kulczyk|Dominika]] (born 1977) and [[Sebastian Kulczyk|Sebastian]] (born 1980).Poland's richest man, Jan Kulczyk, dies at 65, http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/07/29/uk-poland-kulczyk-idUKKCN0Q30PR20150729 ==Muzeum Susch== Muzeum Susch, founded by Kulczyk, will open on 2 January 2019 in [[Susch]], Switzerland.{{Cite web|url=https://www.artforum.com/news/collector-graz-775-yna-kulczyk-to-open-new-experimental-arts-%20space-in-the-swiss-alps-75477|title=Collector Grażyna Kulczyk to Open New Experimental Arts Space in the Swiss Alps|website=www.artforum.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/feedf512-5eae-11e8-ab47-8fd33f423c09|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-09-17}} == Art Stations Foundation / Stary Browar Nowy Taniec == Since 2004 Art Stations Foundation by Grażyna Kulczyk has been providing extensive support to the development of contemporary choreography through its performative programme based in Poznań, recognized internationally under the name Stary Browar Nowy Taniec / Old Brewery New Dance.  Conceived and curated by Joanna Leśnierowska, it provided the Polish and international dance community with a unique meeting point in Central Eastern Europe -  a platform for research, creation and choreographic (self)reflection bringing forward the art of choreography in dialogue with other disciplines, examining its history, theory and future, revisiting and interrogating its own artistic, but also political and social, content and contexts. Stary Browar Nowy Taniec is located at the Stary Browar complex in Poznan, which Grażyna Kulczyk bought in 1998 and sold in 2015.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theartnewspaper.com/news/polish-collector-grazyna-kulczyk-to-launch-vast-contemporary-art-complex-in-secluded-swiss-valley-town|title=Polish collector Grazyna Kulczyk to launch sprawling contemporary art complex in secluded Swiss valley town|website=www.theartnewspaper.com|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{cite news|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/11/30/polish-philanthropist-grazyna-kulczyk-is-seeking-to-open-museum-in-warsaw/|title=Polish Philanthropist, Grazyna Kulczyk, Is Seeking to Open Museum in Warsaw|last1=Berendt|first1=Joanna|date=30 November 2015|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=[[New York Times]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/475032c4-9966-11e3-b3a2-00144feab7de.html|title=Grazyna Kulczyk’s collection on show at Boadilla del Monte, Madrid|last1=Adam|first1=Georgina|date=7 March 2014|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=[[Financial Times]]}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kulczyk, Grazyna}} [[Category:Polish philanthropists]] [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Polish businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Museums in Warsaw]] [[Category:Planned new art museums and galleries]] {{Poland-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
'''High-density solids pumps''' are hydrostatically operating machines which displace the medium being pumped and thus create a flow.
==High-density solids and their transport== High-density solids are mixtures of liquid and solid constituents; examples include farm grain, pulled pork, etc.. Each have their own typical physical and chemical characteristics such as specific weight, solids content, maximum particle size as well as how they behave, for example [[Thixotropy|thixotropically]], abrasively or adhesively.
Typical examples for high-density solids are [[concrete]], [[sludge]]s and [[slurries]].
Within industrial plants many substances with high proportion of solids - such as mechanically dewatered sewage sludges, filter cakes, bituminous coal sludges, waste and process sludges - have to be transported over relatively great distances to landfills or incineration plants.
In principle, long conveying distances can be bridged with mechanical conveying equipment or hydraulic high-density solids pumps.
Types of '''mechanical conveyors''' are [[Conveyor belt|belt]], [[Screw conveyor|screw]] (worm), or [[Conveyor chain#scraper|scraper]]. They are suitable for nearly all types of high-density solids.
'''Hydraulic high-density solids pumps''' move sludges and slurries within an enclosed pipeline. However, not every sludge or slurry is pumpable, depending on: * Ratio: The mixture of solid and liquid components must be such that it results in a plastically deformable mass. * Saturation: The volume of pore space in the sludges must be filled with sufficient quantity of liquid matter for particle to be able to rest on particle via a plastically viscous liquid and for the interstices to be filled. * Gas component: As a consequence of pressure fluctuations, knocking in the pipe may happen. By injection of about 2% air, sludges which do not naturally have a gas component can be brought to a better consistency.
==Types of high-density solids pumps== Depending on how the displacement principle is implemented, a distinction can be drawn between rotary and reciprocating pumps. The rotary circulation pumps includes eccentric screw pumps, [[centrifugal pump]]s, and squeezed tube (peristaltic) pumps. Reciprocating pumps include plunger, diaphragm, and piston pumps.
The high-density solids pumps which can be used in the widest range of situations is the hydraulically powered piston (or reciprocating) pump. It can be realized as single-cylinder or two-cylinder pump. In the latter case, power is transferred to the material via delivery pistons working in push-pull-mode.While one delivery piston sucks material from the feed hopper into the cylinder, the second piston simultaneously pushes the material in the other delivery cylinder and into the delivery line.
The PUMPMAN series pumps invented in INDIA in 2015-16 are however completely different from the presently available hydraulically operated piston pumps. The PUMPMAN series Pumps have been recently invented which do not use a hydraulic pump and complex hydraulic circuits for their operation. However they use a very simple mechanism which multiplies the reciprocating force several times without using a hydraulic system. These Pumps are protected under multiple patent applications, some of them are already published by the Indian Patent office. They have been invented by Amit & Anand Gokhale.<ref>https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/small-concrete-pump-pm-25-d-amit-gokhale?trk=hp-feed-article-title-share</ref>
==Types of piston pumps== <gallery> File:Rohrweichenpumpe.jpg|Piston pump with transfer tube File:Sitzventilpumpe.jpg|Piston pump with seat valve File:Kugelventilpumpe.jpg|Ball valve pump File:Einzylinder-Kolbenpumpe.jpg|Single-cylinder piston pump </gallery>
===Type: Piston pump with transfer tube (two-cylinder pump)=== [[File:Rohrweichenpumpe Animation.ogv|thumb|300px|Operating principle of piston pump with transfer tube]]
====Construction details==== The most characteristic element of the transfer tube pump is the so-called "S" transfer tube installed inside the feed hopper. The job of the transfer tube is to control the flow of high-density solids - in other words, the pump cylinder which is currently pushing the material is connected to the delivery line by such tube. At (or nearby) the end of each piston stroke the S-shaped tube which is connected to the delivery line is swung over to the other delivery cylinder with the aid of two switch cylinders. A hydraulic circuit is used for synchronizing the position of the transfer tube and the movements of the two delivery pistons.
The S tube should swing over rapidly and not suffer undue wear. This is effected with two large-sized plunger cylinders and a so-called spectacle plate (so named from its shape) including seal rings.
In cross section the S-tube is circular with a diameter which tapers in the direction of flow. This keeps the risk of clogging down. The sealing faces of the spectacle plate and of the seal ring lie parallel with the swivelling movement of the S-tube, so that they cannot be damaged when foreign bodies are cut through or get stuck.
This pump does not need check valves.
====Operating features==== Piston pumps with S-tube are suitable for concrete and mortar, for sludges with a solids content of up to 50% by weight and a fluctuating particle size distribution but also for conveying [[fly ash]], coal or minerals in a suspension.
The large cross section of the holes in the spectacle plate means that with a delivery cylinder diameter of e.g. {{Convert|200|mm|in|3|abbr=on}} it is possible to pump high-density solids with a mean grain size of as much as {{Convert|80|mm|in|3|abbr=on}}. The maximum diameter of individual foreign bodies may be as high as 60% of the diameter of the delivery line - in this example this would be {{Convert|120|mm|in|3|abbr=on}}.
===Type: Piston pump with seat valves (two-cylinder pump)=== [[File:Sitzventilpumpe Animation.ogg|thumb|300px|Operating principle of piston pump with seat valves]]
====Construction details==== The steel housing of the seat valve pump contains four hydraulically controlled seat valves, two suction and two delivery valves for the two hydraulic cylinders. The suction and discharge valves are synchronized with the hydraulics of the delivery pistons - this ensures that the contents of the delivery cylinder is equal at all times to the volume being pumped. Once the "sucking" piston reaches its end position, the corresponding suction or delivery valve is simultaneously closed or opened. If there is overpressure in the delivery line, the suction valve will close first. This prevents the pumped medium from being pushed out of the pressure line back into the hopper.
This pump does not need check valves.
====Operating features==== Seat valve pumps are suitable for an especially even pumping of media with a solids content of up to 50% and for the high-pressure pumping of paste-like industrial media such as sludges. Since valves are used in this two-cylinder pump it is suitable for grain sizes up to 8mm at most.
Which type of valve is selected will depend on the high-density solids to be conveyed. For materials containing grains with a solids content up to 50% a sharp-edged metal valve seat is required. With low-viscosity, rather watery fine sludges the choice would be a large-area elastomeric valve seal.
In one hydraulic control variant the valve is opened passively by the thrust of the medium. In this case the discharge valve has a non-return function which prevents flowback from the pressure line. At the same time the high-densitiy solids are precompacted to close to the line pressure before the discharge valve opens. This means that pipe knocking resulting from pressure pulsations can be avoided.
===Type: Ball-valve pump (two-cylinder pump)===
====Construction details==== During the suction stroke of the delivery piston the medium is sucked in via the open suction ball valve. At the same time the ball valve on the delivery line is pushed into the valve seating by the underpressure resulting from the suction (automatic valves). In parallel with this, the second delivery piston is making the pressure stroke and forces the medium through the discharge ball valve and into the delivery line. The suction ball valve is pushed into its seating by the delivery line pressure and thereby closes off the connection to pump intake.
====Operating features==== The two-cylinder ball valve pump is suitable for in the low to middle pressure range for pumping highly liquid to paste-like media provided these can be sucked in through the valve openings - for example mortars, mineral and sewage sludges.
The ball valve pump is to all intents and purposes insensitive to corrosive and abrasive media since the ball valves do not have to be opened or closed from the outside.
===Type: Single-cylinder piston pump===
====Construction details==== With a single-cylinder piston pump the medium is "stuffed" out of a feed chute into the delivery cylinder and by the cylinder into the delivery line on the forward stroke. Depending on the level of the delivery pressure in the pipe and on the flow properties of the medium, the delivery flange of the pump will be fitted with a flat slide valve or a lamellar non-return valve in order to prevent flowback of the material on the return stroke. Which delivery piston is actually selected will depend on the material which is to be pumped: Free flowing media call for perturbane sealing elements while bulky materials which have to be chopped up during pumping mean that hardened cutting edges are required.
====Operating features==== The single-cylinder pump is suitable for bulk materials with an awkward coarse composition - for example wood chips, organic waste, hazardous waste, or shredded paper. If such unsaturated material is to be conveyed over large distances, one possible approach is the hybrid feed system. Here compressed air is injected into the delivery line. It presses the plug of material into the pipe. As the compressed air expands the material being conveyed is loosened and separated. As distance increases from the air injection point, what was initially a series of plugs gradually turns into a continuous airborne stream. The amount of air required and the appropriate pipe diameter depend on the type and quantity of matter being conveyed.
===Type : Single-cylinder piston pump with an off-center three way rotary gate valve=== The said type of gate valve is having a rotating member inside a rotating valve chamber wherein the center of the valve chamber is off-set with the center line of the pumping cylinder and the pumping cylinder and the delivery pipe are on the same axis. Further the value of the off-set decides the thickness of the rotating member's sealing portion as it is provided a cut section equivalent to the diameter of the pumping cylinder. This invention eliminates the through hole design of the rotary valve and also introduces a replaceable cutting edge for the rotating member. Further this valve ensures that it displaces minimum concrete during its operation and ensures elimination of dead zones. Further the symmetrical design of the rotating member & the valve chamber allow the end user to repair the valve by using conventional means of machining such as a normal lathe machine. This impossible with S-tube valve or rock valve. This valve has been invented by Amit and Anand Gokhale.<ref>http://ipindiaonline.gov.in/patentsearch/GrantedSearch/viewdoc.aspx?id=EaXBWM7XcHGElNLd7sM9BA%3d%3d&loc=vsnutRQWHdTHa1EUofPtPQ%3d%3d</ref>
==Parts of high-density solids piston pumps== Main parts are: * feed hopper * drive cylinder, delivery cylinder and hydraulic system * seals * electrical and control equipment and - depending on the type: * transfer tube * valves as well as peripheral components such as: * bunker (with / without sliding frames) * screw conveyors, pre-press equipment * pipework * air injection * boundary layer injection * systems for pressure (pulsation) damping
==Solids pump selection== The special kind of medium "high-density solids" and the wide range of applications require different construction principles and hence pump types. Following table permits a pre-selection depending on the media characteristics: {| align="center" border="1" ! rowspan="2" | Type ! colspan="4" | Medium (high-density solids) |- | watery | stiff | bulky | with foreign bodies |- | Transfer type pump | align="center" | <nowiki>+</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>+ +</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>-</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>+</nowiki> |- | Seat valve pump | align="center" | <nowiki>+ +</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>+</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>-</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>-</nowiki> |- | Ball valve pump | align="center" | <nowiki>+</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>o</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>-</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>-</nowiki> |- | Single-cylinder pump | align="center" | <nowiki>-</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>+ +</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>+ +</nowiki> | align="center" | <nowiki>+ +</nowiki> |- | style="text-align: right;" colspan="5" | + + very suitable,  + suitable,  o with reservations,  - not suitable |}
==Applications== The hydraulic pumping of solids with high solids contents offers a range of possibilities in process engineering. Oil-hydraulically powered two-cylinder piston pumps with S-transfer tube have already been used for many years in civil engineering for transporting concrete. This technology has been transferred to further areas of application in various sectors of industry.
===Sewage treatment plants=== Mechanically dewatered sewage sludge can be pumped directly into furnaces via a pipe network. This avoids direct contact with the sludges and prevents from contamination and odour emission.
===Waste management (Hazardous waste)=== Hazardous and highly flammable substances are processed physically, chemically and biologically in order to reduce the waste materials. With the advantage of pipeline conveyance, high density solids pumps commonly transport such material.
===Mining=== Real tunneling (in other words, not cut-and-cover) has increased palpably in recent years. Conveying [[mine water]], soil and tailings to the tunnel entrance is a need.
==Boundary conditions==
===Transport routes=== Various aspects have to be considered in the planning and processing of conveying installations. This includes the space requirements, the accessibility in case of maintenance or cleaning purposes, as well as horizontal or vertical transport route for material discharge.
===Environmental protection (Noise and odour reduction)=== Due to the nature of the material and the conveying method, odour nuisances is to be expected. Choosing the appropriate conveying method can reduce the environmental pollution
===Energy expenditure=== Three forces have to be overcome when conveying with high density solids pumps:
# The conveying distance (cf. Record held by [[Concrete pump]]) # Friction between material and pipeline, especially in bends and reduction joints. # Inner frictional force caused by deformation of the material. Calculation example: * Conveyance suspension * Delivery line of {{convert|200|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} diameter (DN200) * High-density solids with mineral or carbon content as a mixture from coarse and fine grained material. * Maximum particle size {{convert|50|mm|in|3|abbr=on}} * Dry solids content up to 80 percent by weight Energy consumption = approx. {{convert|50|Wh|abbr=on}} per tonne of conveyed material and per kilometer (280 Btu per long ton or 250 Btu per short ton per mile).
==See also== *[[Concrete pump]] *[[Slurry transport]] *[[Hydraulic transport of solid particles]]

{{Infobox person | name = Igor Rotenberg | residence = Moscow, Russia | nationality = Russian | occupation = Heir }} '''Igor Rotenberg''', ({{lang-ru|Ротенберг, Игорь Аркадьевич born 9 September 1974, [[Saint Petersburg]]}})<ref name=InterfaxInterview2014-10-30>{{cite news|url=https://www.interfax.ru/business/404557|title=Аркадий Ротенберг: мы живем в условиях жесткой конкуренции, но она нас не пугает: Предприниматель рассказал "Интерфаксу" о влиянии санкций на бизнес, о своей дружбе с Путиным и о продаже части активов старшему сыну|language=Russian|trans-title=Arkady Rotenberg: we live in tough competition, but it does not scare us: The businessman told Interfax about the impact of sanctions on business, about his friendship with Putin and about the sale of part of the assets to his eldest son|date=2014-10-30|agency=[[Interfax]]|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref> is a [[Russians|Russian]] [[billionaire]] [[businessman]] and the oldest son and heir to [[Arkady Rotenberg]],<ref name=Isachenkov2018-04-06>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/apr/6/a-look-at-some-of-the-russian-officials-hit-by-us-/|title=A look at some of the Russian officials hit by US sanctions|date=2018-04-06|newspaper=[[The Washington Times]]|last=Isachenkov|first=Vladimir|agency=[[Associated Press]]|access-date=2018-10-03|language=en-US}}</ref> Russian billionaire businessman and co-owner with brother Boris Rotenberg, of the [[Stroygazmontazh|SGM (Stroygazmontazh)]] group.<ref name=ForbesArkady>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/arkady-rotenberg/|title=Arkady Rotenberg|work=[[Forbes]]|access-date=2018-10-03|language=en}}</ref> The Rotenberg's are closely associated with [[Vladimir Putin]].<ref name=Kleptocracy>{{cite book | last = Dawisha | first = Karen | author-link = Karen Dawisha | title = Putin's Kleptocracy: Who Owns Russia? | url = https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1476795207 | year = 2014 | publisher = Simon & Schuster | pages= | isbn = 978-1-4767-9519-5}}</ref> In October 2018, Igor Rotenberg's wealth is estimated to be $1.1 billion.<ref name=ForbesIgor>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/igor-rotenberg|title=Igor Rotenberg|work=[[Forbes]]|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en}}</ref><ref name=Vedimosti2018-04-24>{{cite news|url=https://www.vedomosti.ru/business/news/2018/04/24/767646-igor-rotenberg-prodal-dolyu-za-nedelyu-do-sanktsii|title=Игорь Ротенберг продал долю в TPS Real Estate своей сестре за неделю до санкций|language=Russian|trans-title=Igor Rotenberg sold a share in TPS Real Estate to his sister a week before the sanctions|date=2018-04-24|newspaper=[[Vedomosti]]|last=|first=|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref> Igor Rotenberg has been under [[List of people sanctioned during the Ukrainian crisis|United States sanctions]] since 6 April 2018.<ref name=Isachenkov2018-04-06/><ref name=US-2018-04-06>{{cite web |url=https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm0338 |title=Treasury Designates Russian Oligarchs, Officials, and Entities in Response to Worldwide Malign Activity |publisher= treasury.gov |date=2018-04-06 |access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref><ref name=US180406>{{cite web |url=https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/OFAC-Enforcement/Pages/20180406.aspx |title=Ukraine-/Russia-related Designations and Identification Update; Syria Designations; Kingpin Act Designations; Issuance of Ukraine-/Russia-related General Licenses 12 and 13; Publication of New FAQs and Updated FAQ |publisher=treasury.gov |date= 2018-04-06|access-date= 2018-10-23}}</ref>
Igor is the majority shareholder in Gazprom Drilling.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2017/07/04/commentary/world-commentary/russias-oligarchs-waiting/#.WmBy0q6nGpo|title=Russia's oligarchs-in-waiting {{!}} The Japan Times|work=The Japan Times|access-date=2018-10-03|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Igor Rotenberg was born on 9 September 1974 in [[Leningrad]] to [[Arkady Rotenberg]].<ref name=InterfaxInterview2014-10-30/> In 2002, he graduated from the Higher School of Privatization and Entrepreneurship ({{lang-ru|«Высшей школе приватизации и предпринимательства» (ВШПП)}}) in [[Pushkino, Pushkinsky District, Moscow Oblast|Pushkino]], [[Moscow]], and received his PhD in Law in 2005 in [[Kaliningrad]] at the [[:ru:Калининградский юридический институт МВД России|Kaliningrad Law Institute of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia]] of the [[:ru:Санкт-Петербургский университет МВД России|St. Petersburg University of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia]].<ref name=InterfaxInterview2014-10-30/><ref name=DelovoyIgor>{{cite news|url=http://whoiswho.dp.ru/cart/person/1934338/|title=Кто есть кто: Ротенберг Игорь Аркадьевич|language=Russian|trans-title=Who Is Who: Rotenberg Igor Arkadyevich|work=[[Delovoy Petersburg]]|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref><ref name=Dissertation>{{cite web|url=http://disser.law.edu.ru/disser.asp?disserID=1363196|title=«Недвижимое имущество как объект гражданских прав»|language=Russian|trans-title="Real estate as an object of civil rights"|work=Kaliningrad Law Institute of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia|date=2005-01-01|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref><ref>[http://law.edu.ru/book/book.asp?bookID=1361669 Abstract: Real estate as an object of civil rights] by Rotenberg, I. A. (Igor Arkadyevich), published by the library of the Faculty of Law at the Scientific Library. M. Gorky St. Petersburg State University, updated 2009-12-16.</ref>
==Career== From 2002 to 2003, he was the Deputy Head of the Department of Property of the Fuel and Energy Complex in the Ministry of Property of Russia which later became [[Federal Agency for State Property Management]] in 2004.<ref name=DelovoyIgor/> From 2003 to 2004, he was the Head of the Department of Transport and Telecommunications Property for the Property of Russia.<ref name=DelovoyIgor/> From 2004 to 2005, he was the Vice-President of [[Russian Railways]] OJSC and acted as the Head of the Department of Property Management and Organizational Structures.<ref name=DelovoyIgor/> Since 2006, he is the owner and the [[Chairman]] of the Board of Directors of the [[Moscow]]-based NPV Engineering Group.<ref name=DelovoyIgor/><ref name=BloombergNPV>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=271354617|title=Company Overview of NPV Engineering|work=[[Bloomberg Business]]|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref>{{efn|In 2015 to reduce Russia's dependence of imports of antimony trioxide, the NPV Engineering Group of [[Moscow]] began building a plant for the production of [[antimony trioxide]] in [[Degtyarsk]], [[Sverdlovsk Oblast|Sverdlovsk]].<ref name=Vedomosti2015-07-14>{{cite news|url=https://www.vedomosti.ru/business/news/2015/07/14/600519-igor-rotenberg-vlozhilsya-v-zavod-po-proizvodstvu-surmi|title=Игорь Ротенберг вложился в завод по производству сурьмы|language=Russian|trans-title=Igor Rotenberg invested in antimony plant|date=2015-07-14|agency=[[Interfax]]|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref>}} Since 2008, he is the Vice-President of the design bureau CB "[[Northern Sea Route]]" ({{lang-ru|конструкторское бюро ЦБ «Северный морской путь» (Севморпуть)}}).<ref name=DelovoyIgor/> Since 2010, he is the Chairman of the Board of Directors of [[Mosenergo|Mosenergo Heat and Power Company]].<ref name=DelovoyIgor/> Since 2011, he is the Chairman of the Board of Directors of [[:ru:Газпром бурение|Gazprom Burenie LLC]] (Burgaz).<ref name=DelovoyIgor/>
In 2015, Arkady Rotenberg sold his son Igor Rotenberg a number of assets including up to 79% of Gazprom Drilling (Bureniye),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/3a5326d0-3ce4-11e5-bbd1-b37bc06f590c|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> 28% of the road contruction company Mostotrest,<ref name=ForbesNikolaev>{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.ru/milliardery/365049-partner-druzey-putina-chem-izvesten-sponsor-russkoy-shpionki-butinoy|title=Партнер друзей Путина: чем известен спонсор «русской шпионки» Бутиной|language=Russian|trans-title=Partner of Putin's friends: what is known for the sponsor of the "Russian spy" Butina|date=July 23, 2018|work=[[Forbes]]|last=Пастушин|first=Алексей (Pastushin, Alexey)|access-date=October 18, 2018}}</ref>{{efn|While he was the [[Ministry of Transport (Russia)|Minister of Transport of the Russian Federation]] from May 20, 2004 to 2012, [[Igor Levitin]] ensured in 2010 that Arkady Rotenberg's firms would contruct the toll roads on Russian federal highways.<ref name=Vedomosti2010-09-20>{{cite news|url=https://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/articles/2010/09/20/dorogami_kovalchuka_i_rotenberga|title=Платные дороги в России строят только знакомые Владимира Путина: Через несколько лет в России появятся две первые платные дороги. Обе идут из Москвы и строятся фактически на государственные деньги. За обеими стоят петербургские знакомые Владимира Путина: Юрий Ковальчук и Аркадий Ротенберг|language=Russian|trans-title=Only Putin’s friends build toll roads in Russia: In a few years, the first two toll roads will appear in Russia. Both come from Moscow and are actually built on public money. Behind both are Vladimir Putin’s Saint Petersburg acquaintances: Yuri Kovalchuk and Arkady Rotenberg|date=September 20, 2010|newspaper=[[Vedomosti]]|last=Сагдиев|first=Ринат (Sagdiev, Rinat)|access-date=October 27, 2018}}</ref><ref name=LevitinBio>{{cite web|url=http://kremlin.ru/catalog/persons/151/biography|title=Левитин, Игорь Евгеньевич|language=Russian|trans-title=Levitin, Igor Yevgenyevich|work=kremlin.ru|access-date=October 27, 2018}}</ref>}} and 33.3% of [[Jersey]]-based TPS Real Estate Holdings Ltd.<ref name=RBC2018-04-19>{{cite news|url=https://www.rbc.ru/business/19/04/2018/5ad75b649a794710aa3b96ee|title=Партнеры Аркадия Ротенберга наняли лоббистов в США: Совладельцы аэропорта Шереметьево Александр Пономаренко и Александр Скоробогатько наняли фирму для лоббирования своих интересов в США. Оба бизнесмена — давние партнеры попавшего под санкции Аркадия Ротенберга и его сына Игоря|language=Russian|trans-title=Arkady Rotenberg's partners hired lobbyists in the US: Sheremetyevo Airport co-owners Alexander Ponomarenko and Alexander Skorobogatko hired a company to lobby their interests in the United States. Both businessmen are longtime partners who fell under the sanctions of Arkady Rotenberg and his son Igor|date=2018-04-19|work=[[RBK Group|RBC]]|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref><ref name=Vedomosti2015-05-17>{{cite news|url=https://www.vedomosti.ru/realty/articles/2015/05/18/struktura-igorya-rotenberga-sina-milliardera-arkadiya-rotenberga-mozhet-postroit-transportno-peresadochnii-uzel|title=Структура Игоря Ротенберга может построить транспортно-пересадочный узел: Размер инвестиций – до $340 млн|language=Russian|trans-title=The structure of Igor Rotenberg can build a transport hub: Investment size - up to $340 million|date=2015-05-17|newspaper=[[Vedomosti]]|last1=Ляув|first1=Бэла (Love, Bela)|last2=Филатов|first2=Антон (Filatov, Anton)|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref> [[Alexander Ponomarenko]] and [[Aleksandr Skorobogatko]] own 66.6% of TPC Real Estates Holdings.<ref name=RBC2018-04-19/><ref name=Forbes2018-01-30>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/igorbosilkovski/2018/01/30/treasury-departments-russias-oligarchs-list-is-copied-from-forbes/#20e1807a6825 |title=Treasury Department's Russia Oligarchs List Is Copied From Forbes |date=2018-01-30 |work=[[Forbes]] |last=Bosilkovsky |first=Igor |access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref><ref name=Interfax2018-10-30>{{cite news|url=https://www.interfax.ru/business/404725|title=Игорь Ротенберг выкупил у отца "Газпром бурение" и долю в "ТПС Недвижимости"|language=Russian|trans-title=Igor Rotenberg bought out of his father Gazprom drilling and a share in TPS Real Estate|date=2014-10-30|agency=[[Interfax]]|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref>
It was reported that Arkady Rotenberg made this move after being placed on the [[International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis|U.S. sanctions list]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/russian-asset-sales-muddy-sanction-compliance-1423784903|title=Russian Asset Sales Muddy Sanction Compliance|last=Ensign|first=Rachel Louise|date=2015-02-12|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-10-03|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
In 2015, OJCS TPS Real Estate ({{lang-ru|ОАО «ТПС недвижимость»}}) is one of the largest commercial real estate developers in Russia that manages several shopping centers in Russia and [[Ukraine]].<ref name=Vedomosti2015-05-17/> It is 100% owned by TPS Real Estate Holding Ltd.<ref name=Vedomosti2015-05-17/> It owns the [[Krasnodar]] Gallery ({{lang-ru|ТРЦ «Галерея Краснодар»}}), [[Sochi]]'s Moremoll ({{lang-ru|ТРЦ «Моремолл»}}), and Kiev's Ocean Plaza ({{lang-ru|ТРЦ «Ocean Plaza»}}). It is building the [[Novosibirsk]] Gallery ({{lang-ru|ТРЦ «Галерея Новосибирск»}}) and [[Moscow]]'s [[Slavyansky Bulvar|Slavyansky Boulevard metro station]] and [[Polezhayevskaya|Polezhayevskaya metro station]].<ref name=Vedomosti2015-05-17/> At the end of 2016, TPS Real Estate managed 12 shopping center with a total area of over 2 million square meters.<ref name=Vedomosti2015-05-17/>
In 2016, Igor Rotenberg was at the center of a controversy surrounding [[:ru:Платон (система взимания платы)|Platon]], a company he half-owns, and alleged discrepancies in its contracts with the federal road agency, [[Federal Road Agency (Russia)|Rosavtodor]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/moscow-court-orders-rotenberg-company-to-reveal-platon-tax-system-deal-51626|title=Moscow Court Orders Rotenberg Company to Reveal Platon Tax System Deal|access-date=2018-10-03|language=en}}</ref> Operated by RT Invest, the Platon toll system electronically tracks and charges tolls to trucks over 12 tons on Russian Federal roads.<ref name=RBC2015-12-29>{{cite news|url=https://www.rbc.ru/business/29/12/2015/56826ecb9a79471719a0032b|title=Версия Навального: как зарабатывает оператор системы «Платон»: Компания-оператор системы «Платон» до 2027 года будет гарантированно получать из бюджета 9,9 млрд руб. в год, вне зависимости от выставленных штрафов, следует из документа, опубликованного Алексеем Навальным|language=Russian|trans-title=Navalny version: how the operator of the Plato system earns: The company-operator of the system “Plato” until 2027 will be guaranteed to receive from the budget 9.9 billion rubles. per year, regardless of the fines imposed, follows from a document published by Alexei Navalny|date=2018-12-29|work=[[RBK Group|RBC]]|last=Телегина|first=Наталия (Telegina, Nataliya)|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref> With a 25% ownership by Rotenberg and using satellite tracking data, ScanEx ({{lang-ru|ООО «ГК Сканэкс»}}), a subsidiary of RT Invest, is developing an electronic map of the {{convert|50000|km|mi|abbr=on}} of Russian federal roads in order to track vehicles for payment to Platon.<ref name=Kommersant2015-11-18>{{cite news|url=https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/2856295|title=Вышли на трассу: Кто участвует в создании системы "Платон"|language=Russian|trans-title=Out on the track: Who is involved in the creation of the system "Plato"|date=2015-11-18|newspaper=[[Kommersant]]|last=Новый|first=Владислав (Novoy, Vladislav)|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref>{{efn|Competitors of ScanEx are Sovzond ({{lang-ru|«Совзонд»}}), Data East ({{lang-ru|«Дата Ист»}}), and others.<ref name=Kommersant2015-11-18/>}} Approved on 29 September 2014 by Roman Starovoyt ({{lang-ru|Роман Старовойт}}), who is the head of Rosavtodor, and Alexander Sovetnikov ({{lang-ru|Александр Советников}}), who is the director of RT - Invest Transport Systems (RTITS) ({{lang-ru|«РТ-Инвест Транспортные системы»}}), Rotenberg, through his companies,{{efn|Igor Rotenberg owns RTITS and co-owns RT-Invest with Andrey Shipelov's ({{lang-ru|Андрей Шипелов}}) Tsaritsyn Capital ({{lang-ru|ООО «Царицын Капитал»}}) and [[Rostec]] ({{lang-ru|«Ростех»}}).<ref name=Kommersant2015-11-18/>}} is guaranteed to receive from the state budget a very large portion of the 10.6 billion rubles indexed to inflation each year without VAT (4.98 billion rubles paid semi-annually) from November 15, 2015, to September 29, 2027, which is paid to the Planton & RT Invest partnership.<ref name=RBC2015-12-29/> After this was revealed, a [[:ru:Забастовка дальнобойщиков в России|large strike across Russia by truck drivers]] occurred on Russian federal highways beginning November 2015.<ref name=BBC2015-11-23>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/russian/news/2015/11/151123_gref_trucks_tariffs|title=Греф: дорожные сборы с дальнобойщиков усилят инфляцию на 1,5%|language=Russian|trans-title=Gref: road tolls charged to truckers will increase because of inflation by 1.5%|date=2015-11-23|work=[[BBC]]|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref> Insted of the expected total revenues from Platon of 20 to 40 billion rubles, the actual revenues were 25% or less than those figures.<ref name=BBC2016-03-16>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/russian/news/2016/03/160316_platon_income|title=Минтранс: "Платон" собирает в два раза меньше денег, чем ожидалось|language=Russian|trans-title=Ministry of Transport: "Plato" collects a quarter the money expected|date=2016-03-16|work=[[BBC]]|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref>
On 29 March 2018, Igor sold his 33.3% stake in TPS Real Estate Holdings for $1 billion to his sister Liliya Rotenberg ({{lang-ru|Лилия Аркадьевичнa Ротенберг born 17 April 1978}}).<ref name=Vedimosti2018-04-24/><ref name=RBC2018-04-19/><ref name=RBC2018-04-24>{{cite news|url=https://www.rbc.ru/business/24/04/2018/5addb07f9a794761ea858c8c|title=Родственная сделка: почему Игорь Ротенберг продал долю в TPS Real Estate: Игорь Ротенберг, который с 6 апреля находится в санкционном списке Минфина США, за неделю до этого вышел из состава акционеров девелоперской компании TPS Real Estate. Новым совладельцем стала его сестра Лилия Ротенберг|language=Russian|trans-title=Related transaction: why Igor Rotenberg sold his stake in TPS Real Estate: Igor Rotenberg, who has been on the sanctions list of the US Treasury since April 6, a week before, left the shareholders of the real estate development company TPS Real Estate. New sister was his sister Lilia Rotenberg|date=2018-04-24|work=[[RBK Group|RBC]]|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref>
==Sanctions== On 6 April 2018, Igor Rotenberg and his NPV Engineering Group were placed under [[List of people sanctioned during the Ukrainian crisis|United States sanctions]].<ref name=Isachenkov2018-04-06/><ref name=US-2018-04-06/><ref name=US180406/><ref name=White&Case2018-04-11>{{cite news|url=https://www.whitecase.com/publications/alert/us-sanctions-prominent-russian-individuals-and-companies|title=US Sanctions Prominent Russian Individuals and Companies|date=2018-04-11|work=[[White & Case]]|location=[[New York City]]|last1=Burke|first1=Richard|last2=Erb|first2=Nicole|last3=Delelle|first3=Claire A.|last4=Zissis|first4=Kristina|last5=Brayton-Lewis|first5=Cristina|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref>
==Wealth== In October 2018, Igor Rotenberg had an estimated wealth of $1.1 billion by [[Forbes]].<ref name=ForbesIgor/>
==Personal life== He is married and has three children.<ref name=ForbesIgor/>
==Notes== {{notelist}}
